title: Expect more AND less, means to an end
pros: Depending on the staff you will be working with some very talented individuals. You will learn a lot from your co workers even if you have worked in fine dining previously. Take full advantage of Forbes steps of service training & wine classes. Every day you are expected to bring the very best to your all guests(especially VIP). If you take pride in your work this can be a satisfying place to work. Benefits are available but be sure you are working over 50 hours a week including Sunday Brunch & holidays. Best part of the job was definitely my co workers and some favorite celebrities.
cons:
The pay does not compensate for the long shifts and amount of work/talent expected. Not only must you work Sunday brunch to guarantee a decent paycheck but all tips are pooled (cash & credit) with cooks, floor valets, vehicle valets, front desk. In the summer months when the place gets rocked, they bring on employees from an exchange program. Tips are NOT POOLED with these employees! They make all the money in the summer that you prayed for in the winter. Not only do they barely speak English but the same standard of service does not apply. 

On another note, if you ever have an issue with a manager harassing you, don’t expect HR to be at all helpful. We had a meeting with my attacker and nothing was done even with a witness.

title: You Only Get A Small Percent of Your Tips
pros: Beautiful Facility and Watch Hill is gorgeous
cons: If you depend on your career as a server to pay your bills then you won’t be able to here! You only receive a small part of the tips you make because of a tip pool. And the pool is not equally divided! I made $1000 in tips in one week and only received $350 of it in my pay check.  And you work harder here than anywhere else you’ll ever be a sever… I only made it 2 months and had to go somewhere else that pays what I earn.

title: The disrespect
pros: Management does not care about you. I was here four years, picked up everyone's shifts and always stayed late to help out, because I wanted the team to do well. Management took advantage of my kindness and would tell me  I had to stay for the night shift (usually out around 11 pm) after coming in for 7 am., not ask. My schedule that was posted would constantly be changed without my knowledge. There is no such thing as a raise and favoritism is at a high. They don't care how long you're shift is, if you're working ten hours (typical base shift) and it's busy you don't get a break, and stepping off to even pee is looked down on.
cons: Uniforms provided and washed for you. Free food at break if you get one.

title: The worst imaginable
pros: The view is gorgeous and the idea of working at such a prestigious property is awesome!
cons: Have you listened to the podcast The Dropout?  The culture is exactly like that. The employees are dedicated to fulfilling the five star luxury dream however the employees are treated so terribly and are so fearful for their jobs and for the executives ruining their careers within the industry they stay. The turnover is unreal... which is what happens when the executives talk about people like dogs and expect them to work 70 plus hours a week. Employees and managers are called every name in the book.  Another review says run far away. Truer words have never been spoken. Work here only if you want to be treated badly... find out why the person before you left and why there have been 7 people in your potential job in the last few years. Run.

cons: Really enjoying my time here!

title: State employees are treated poorly
pros: Nice coworkers, patients treated well, time off accrues fast
cons: State employees do not get raises, the starting pay is extremely low for the clinical research industry, promotions do not lead to a raise, no tuition reimbursement, very high turnover, no career development, little advancement opportunity, parking is off site using shuttle and expensive, mandatory 5% retirement taken out of checks, HR people are terrible and rude, no performance evaluations, never told when there are problems, line managers are often not qualified or adequately trained to manage, non-reappointments occur in March when they basically fire people they think are overpaid, almost no communication from directors, zero communications from the hospital side, no work-life flexibility, absolutely no working from home, coworkers tattle when you don’t work enough hours, office gossip is out of control and doesn’t help that there is almost no management communication, they hire totally unqualified people and expect their team to just train them, work is not even close to equally distributed, I could go on.

title: Management needs to listen and not enough staff in the clinics.
pros: Benefits, paid holidays in the clinic, getting to parking in a parking garage.
cons: Management doesn’t listen to the people who work in the clinics. They are the ones who know how make the clinic function better. Not enough staff in the clinic for how fast we are growing. The parking is ok depending where you are.

title: Toxic work environment, clinging desperately the abusive "old guard" practices of training future scientists
pros: Many, many excellent resources to facilitate pursuit of research interests (e.g. core facilities, internal bridge funding, leadership training, professional development)
cons:
Toxic environment that is abusive to postdocs and staff scientists
Reinforcement of negative behaviors by institutional leadership
Lack of willingness to advance best talent
Little to no HR oversight of management of research staff
Negative interactions between KUMC business units (occupational health, parking services) and their customers (employees)

title: Zero resource development
pros: Good question!! There isn't much positive about working there. Certainly, nothing worth mentioning.
cons: Management lacks the ability and desire to develop staff. Often hire people without experience, then fail to help them succeed, then fire them for their failure to succeed.

title: Amazing place to work
pros: Lots of opportunity for advancement, excellent work/life balance, very low stress most of the time, SO MUCH PTO, incredibly generous 401k contribution, great gym on site (and free yoga over lunch once a week), urgent care for employees on site even for non-job related needs, very convenient if you have a lot of doctor appointments... could probably list more - TONS of pros.
cons: Parking is pretty inconvenient, and there are some people who get a bit big for their britches sometimes. That's about it though. Very insignificant in the grand scheme of things.

title: A great place for graduate study in biomedical sciences
pros: The medical center offers a great opportunity to study human health related sciences.
cons: This is not really a con, depending on how you look at it. Unlike big universities where graduate students usually work as teaching assistants. Graduate students here only work as research assistant, so that you can focus more on your research. But if you are looking for some teaching experience for your graduate studies, you might not get much from here.

title: Neuromuscular Division Specific
pros: KU Med has incredible benefits and continues to strive towards being better. It's clear this institution is heading in the right direction with generous sick leave, programs to donate sick leave to other employees, vacation leave is a separate pool, adequate maternity leave, etc.
cons:
Overall, the institution is great to work for but this varies from department to department. Therefore, I want to disclaim that this review is based solely on experiences with the Neuromuscular Division. I did not leave this position negatively (fired, etc.) and was even offered a raise during my time here, but would like to offer my honest opinion of my time within this team.

The Neuromuscular Division is lacking in organization and leadership leading to a dysfunctional environment with little to no training but high accountability. The training process if poorly structured and mostly 'learn as you go' - you are expected to perform near perfectly and will be met with strong criticism when mistakes are made. You will be told during interviews that "mistakes happen and that's ok" but will quickly learn this sentiment holds no weight. Very minimal praise is given and your accomplishments will go largely unnoticed. Many of the physicians are great to work with with exclusion to the team leader. He has fostered an environment of fear with his low tolerance of mistakes; discipline even being doled out in front of team members at meetings. There is an adopted method of 'bullying' employees into quitting and very high turnover in this department. An exit interview was requested, but was never granted. Overall, it seems the institution is allowing this destructive environment to continue within this department and thus the high turnover rate continues. If you are considering Clinical Research Coordinator positions at KU Med, consider other departments.

title: Depends on your department a lot
pros: KUMC has a huge reach in KC and all over the state of Kansas. Some of their facilities, including the Clinical Research Center, are beautiful.

title: Great Culture
pros:
Company is based on meritocratic systems with clear defined goals for advancement within the organization. In depth paid training is offered on a regular basis. Benefits include  Paid time off, Paid sick leave, Paid days where employees are encouraged to donate their time back to the community via non profit organizations, and group supplemental benefits for things like dental, accident and disability are also offered. 

Everyone is encouraged to work together and share knowledge as a group. Its cheesy to say but there really is a family culture within the company.
cons: If you are not an extrovert or a motivated introvert this might not be a good fit for you due to the nature of our industry.

title: Great place to work!
pros: They are more than willing to make accommodations for the right employee.  They took a chance on me and we were a great match!
cons:
Only 2 minorish cons:
They don't post a weekly schedule.  They post it every night by 8pm for the  next day.  As a single mom that wasn't always the best situation for me.

The other con is that being a 3rd party vendor inside a Sam's Club means that a Sam's Club employee lied about me cursing her out so even though 86 had my back and supported me, Sam's club still said I wasn't allowed to continue working in their store.

title: This is not a Marketing job it’s door to door sales/ MLM
pros: There aren’t any at all
cons:
This is NOT a Marketing company. You won’t be doing exciting things like tapping into data analytics, marketing automation, content strategy, social media strategy, implementing growth with google ads/ paid search ETC- everything a real marketing person does. It’s 2019. 

Door to door sales is not a real marketing job. 

I love their fake reviews on here. Don’t waste your time

title: An enjoyable place to work
pros:
- Interesting projects with very capable people
- Cross-functional working: tech is not siloed from business
- An unusually genuine commitment to improving customer outcomes
- Ample opportunities to grow in your career - if you're willing to ask for them
- Relaxed and friendly office culture (certainly no face time culture)
cons:
- Although opportunities to develop are there, don't expect them always to be handed to you. You need to feel comfortable advocating for your own career because it won't necessarily happen automatically
- Over the last year, management has done a good job of weathering some of the typical growing pains of a scale-up, and is mostly reaping the benefits of this investment in culture and people. However, processes, risk management and compliance frequently take priority over innovation, and this looks set to continue as Zopa becomes a bank. If you're a pure innovator, you'll be frustrated by the roadblocks that will inevitably slow you
- Zopa is not a hyper-growth scaler. Granted, it moves faster than incumbents and takes carefully measured risks. But the vision is not one of world domination in the next three years, it's of considered entry into markets where Zopa sees unique competitive advantage. As such, the vision for the future is not as exciting as your Monzo's and Revolut's - but it's potentially more realistic

title: Great culture and people
pros:
I look forward to coming in to work at Zopa more than any place I've worked before.

- The culture is pretty unique: fun but focused on results, you get treated like an adult and given independence to follow things that you're passionate about while being supported to get there. 

Perks: 

- Friday drinks and social events, free fruit and breakfast, good gym in the building
- Nice office with a range of spaces to work
- Passionate friendly and intelligent people full of ambition
cons: We get so much done but sometimes need to stop and reflect on success before moving on the next new idea!

title: Looking for something refreshing ? This is the place to be !
pros: Zopa aims to employ likeminded people that really care about what they do and the difference they can make. If you want to get recognised and be involved in making a true difference within the future of banking then this is the place to be! Everyone is actively encouraged to “be yourself”. It’s a hugely refreshing working environment with a culture to match. The values aren’t  just ‘words on a wall’, employees really live out the values here and this includes the Exec Board!  You can sense the difference as soon as you walk through the door where the overarching goal is to #makemoneyfeelgood Employees are empowered by the ‘Tribe’ organisational structure to figure out how best to service a customers evolving needs and then create it! It’s a place where great people do some super cool great things, it’s a place that you can be proud to work!
cons: Honestly, I can’t think of any!

title: Sinking ship, sadly
pros:
Great office location. Brilliant, friendly colleagues. Lots of smart people .

There are some people that really care about the welfare of their colleagues.
cons:
Zopa have completely lost their way. When I first joined I was excited to be part of such a vibrant, caring and determined company but that feeling faded over my first year. Bad decisions have been consistently taken, for example changing the tech stack completely - isolating many of the developers who made Zopa what it was. Most have now departed. 

Anything bank related take top priority, understandably, but is managed and led with such incompetence. Whilst other companies obtain bank licences with (seeming) ease, Zopa can't launch a single product needed to get theirs. Products, projects, ideas are constantly shelved and replaced with workarounds and stopgaps. Infrastructure is ready to collapse. The amount of manual process is farcical. 

It's luck of the draw in regards to whether you'll be looked after by zopa or not. If you draw the short straw, it can be a really tough place to work.  Managers are often looking to offload their pressure and shortcomings onto their direct reports and it happens all too often

title: A company losing its way.
pros:
- Bottom-up culture is strong; there are a lot of good people doing their best to deliver under tricky circumstances.
- HR department really care about their employees; strong initiatives both professionally and personally to support staff.
- Decent perks; free breakfast & healthcare, subsidised gym downstairs, flexible working.
- Pay in-line with comparable firms.
cons:
- Given the firm's start-up roots, there is a serious lack of organisation and structure around decision-making. As such, senior leadership often act autonomously, without consideration for either their own team, or others across the firm. The thought process behind these decisions are then, more often than not, not explained to staff, leaving them confused and disenfranchised.
- Existing staff, despite having had multiple interviews to make an internal transfer, have suddenly been told that the company is now under a 'hiring freeze', despite job adverts since being advertised online. For often years of service, these staff have now been rewarded with having promises broken.

title: Treated unfairly
pros: Just free breakfast - nice river view
cons: I have never been treated so disgusting by a company. The department is very clicky - if you do not fit in, or zopian enough you will not stand a chance here.  I was asked to leave after a week of working there, not sure on what grounds, I was just told they received a lot of negative feedback, none of which was really explained. The parts that were explained to me were extremely petty and sounded like excuses. The manager was almost in tears when they asked me to leave which had me questioning what really the reason was for my termination. I was asked to leave with immediate effect couldn’t collect my things myself or go back upstairs. I felt like I was being treated like some sort of criminal. The HR lady was patronising and said when I left 'at least today is a nice day, you can enjoy the sun'. I didn't feel that comment was very considerate after sacking someone for pretty much no reason. If the people who you work with is important to you, I would consider working here.

title: Not a good place for .NET developers
pros: The office is in a good location. The CEO is a nice guy that is doing a good job in transforming the company into a bank.
cons:
The .NET stack has been neglected in favour of Java/Kotlin rewrites of most services. As a result, several .NET devs have left over the last 12 months. This leaves Zopa in a vulnerable position because the core of the P2P business still runs on .NET. I suspect that the remaining few .NET devs will also checkout over the coming months, as better opportunities are available in London.

P2P investors/lenders have seen little improvement to the slow user experience and confusing dashboard. This is due to an ongoing controversial rewrite of the investor platform which shows no sign of being complete any time soon.

The marketing material is often cringe-inducing!

title: Lots of good promises, not always following through
pros:
Great, smart people
Ethos is spot on with trying to do something good
Enthusiasm for what they want to achieve
cons:
Lack of follow through with professional development
Flat structure causes a lot of miscommunication
Management not always aware what projects are happening and crossing over
Employees who pick up slack are not always the ones rewarded

cons: - Lots to get done so jobs are very busy

The Friday Company Meeting is great for joining the dots so we all know what's going on and feel a part of the journey.
cons: Location too great?  Office too cool?  Work too interesting?  People too lovely?  Nope - can't think of any!

cons: Chairs are not comfortable and broke a lot. Office is not cleaned properly.

There is a wide range of people at Zopa with all have very different skill-sets, so it's not a bad place to learn new skills from others.
cons: Things can move frustratingly slowly and often other parts of the business that you rely on to get a task done feels unconnected or unconcerned. If you are looking to be part of a dynamic and fast-paced company, this is not it.

title: Proud to work for USHealth Group
pros: USHealth Group offers a very positive work environment. We operate as one big family. We work hard, and when it's time to play, we play hard too. As an ambitious employee, I know the opportunity to advance my career is available and important to upper management. Continuing Education and training is a tremendous benefit. Our pay and benefit package is very competitive, and our HR team is always looking for ways to make it better.
cons: I believe one thing that can help increase employee satisfaction and productivity is flex scheduling and work from home options. Work/life balance is extremely important to most employees. They want to be assured of the ability to be present for their family's special moments. The company will find this increases employee morale, reduces absenteeism and tardiness, and increases their ability to recruit outstanding employees.

title: If you work hard, it pays off
pros:
If you work hard, get CREATIVE with creating leads, utilizing the leads the company  provides as well as networking,  this opportunity can be whatever you make of it.  
If you are a great salesperson, truly care about your clients, then the sky is the limit with USHealth.  However, if you are not a great salesperson, feel that the leads provided are the only way to go, then this is not the opportunity for you.  I work in THE most supportive environment I have EVER worked in, love the group of people I work with and the opportunity laid out before me.  I have found a home here!
cons: You must work hard for what you want.

title: Great Company!  Great People!
pros: This company is fantastic!  Not only does this company care about helping other people (our clients) but they care about helping their employees.  The compensation is fantastic and it doesn't stop there!  There are weekly, monthly, quarterly incentives and award trips!  You even get stock just for doing your job...helping other people every day.  The management team and co-workers are great!  Most sales jobs are cut throat, not this one.  Everyone is ready to help with what works well for them.  It's a great environment to work in.
cons: Your income is all up to you!  Not a con in my opinion.  You just have to have a strong work ethic and you will do well!

title: US Health Group is an amazing place to work
pros: Career Growth, great benefits, flexible with vacation time off, overall a wonderful place to work, I enjoy what I do Helping Other People Everyday which is our goal HOPE
cons: no cons that I have come across

title: greatest blessing of my life
pros: flexibility to spend time with your family while making fantastic income at the same time. Ability to have complete support from the company while being self employed at the same time. I have been able to make more than 10 times my previous income in just 3 years-I love what I do-fantastic company.
cons: no health insurance and other benefits (don't really mind since I'm making about 10 times my previous income). It is a lot of hard work to get started out for the first few months you really need to hit the ground hard.

title: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!
pros: I have been in the Customer Service field since 2000..but I've never been treated as great as USHealth Group treats me. They seriously value their employees! I love coming to work and I am so honored to be able to have this opportunity to grow in my career here. Unless I win the lottery, or one of my albums make me become famous at singing, I will be right here loving my career at USHealth Group!!!
cons: no cons...this is the best place to work for!

title: Starting a career
pros:
Competitive payment
Advancement opportunities
Company growth and job security
Amazing management
Great company values
Staff and Management
cons: With any customer service position and working as a call center rep it can be high stress on certain days. Large call volumes and the occasional inconsolable customer can be hard to deal with at times.

title: Tread Lightly
pros:
Told you're able to work your own hours, positive atmosphere, managers are very supportive, paid in advance for underwritten sales.

GREAT product, which is why I stayed as long as I did.
cons:
TONS of inaccurate info given throughout the hiring process..

You're originally told you can choose your hours, but then managers harass you to be there 8am-8pm and weekends. They promote work/life balance as a benefit, but it's a complete misconception. To make a decent living (40K/year) you pretty much have to stay chained to your computer waiting for a new lead at all times.

They don't disclose that it will take several months to make any money at all, so you need to have a fantastic savings or someone else to support you.

You pay $100 per month for the "company provided leads." You have to make 400 dials a day on average to make a sale, and most the leads are angry people who are sick of their phone being blown up. You better be able to handle being screamed and cussed at!

They're well aware of the astronomical turnover rate, so their first goal is to get  as many of your friends and family members as clients. That way when you leave they're still benefiting off you.

Several morally questionable Marketing strategies being used by upper management and top company producers via Nextdoor, Facebook, etc.

Underwriting is extremely tedious and frustrating for the clients and agents. You'll rarely get the same answer twice to a question, because the representatives are all on a different pages and don't know company policies well enough. With businesses and families especially, it can sometimes take months to get an approval decision.

title: Huge Potential!
pros: The potential income at U.S. Health is amazing. 100k first year is very doable with hard work and dedication.
cons: Commission only pay structure. Slower times can be difficult if you're not disciplined in money management.

From an operations standpoint that is frustrating to understand the direction of the company. A lot of turnover across the board. The office is painfully quiet with a handful of people that give off an "unhappy with their jobs" vibe.  They don't have WiFi for employees and don't allow usage of music apps so I used my phone data all day for music (again painfully quiet). I wasn't excited to go to work and knew it wouldn't get better. In other words, bad culture. I was not going to spend my time waiting for them to slowly turn the ship around. Not worth it.

cons: There is not a lot of support for new employees. Some disorganized communication.

title: Fabulous culture and people, and interesting projects
pros:
* Fabulous, healthy culture and people
* Great benefits (except for health insurance, see below)
* They don't tolerate the "brilliant jerk" -- you know the type that alienates everyone, sabotages colleagues' mental health, and makes the group culture toxic. Not at Waters!
cons:
* Health insurance benefits could be better: two high-deductible plans by Aetna, which doesn't have great coverage in my experience. I would have preferred a Massachusetts-based plan, such as Harvard Pilgrim Health Plan, Tufts Health Plan, or BCBSMA.
* Quite far from Boston, relatively. With traffic, my commute from Boston is an hour each way.

title: Changing times at Waters, but is it for the better?
pros: Intelligent staff and great technology. Fantastic field organization that are truly invested in customer success.
cons: New CEO seems like he should run for public office, not run a technology business.  Internal business systems are from the dark ages. Things are being done to modernize but it's about 15-20 years too late.

title: Marketing Manager
pros:
Some smart and talented people.. but they are dropping like flies. 
I can’t think of any other pros.
cons:
Poor leadership and lack of qualified managers. It’s a sinking ship and all of the best employees have left or are planning their exit. Culture of fear and dishonesty. Lack of trust and pervasive back stabbing is the norm.
Lack of transparency and trust is pervasive and corrosive. 
Awful health insurance and terrible bare minimum maternity leave and zero paternity leave.

title: Great Place to Work at All Stages of Your Career
pros: Professional, yet warm, friendly atmosphere.  Many 30+ year employees.  One company that values both the senior, experienced employee as well as the newer college graduates starting their careers.  Nice mix.
cons: Haven't seen any big ones yet.  Do recognize that there is a push to update processes to keep up with competition.  So far not too disruptive, although necessary.

title: Pay scale is sub-par, the best salary will be negotiated in the beginning.
pros: Waters seems to have a stable overall business plan. Fairly new facility design offers employees comfort and perks.
cons: What was once a good culture is on the downslide and reinventing a new personality. Recently witnessed many tenured employees getting released. New employees seem safe but tenured employees seem targeted. Makes me nervous!

title: GMP people get ready to bend everything you were previously taught
pros: Don’t settle for anything less than 80k, a company car, and a home office. Flexibility to make your own schedule. Take advantage of all trainings you can.  Make as many connections as possible. Other vendors are always looking to take advantage of the referral incentive.
cons:
I said get ready ... Imagine you now or previously worked in a GMP regulated lab. Be prepared to walk up to instruments you’ve never seen before or been trained on and be told by your manager that you have to do it. Most companies don't ask for your training certs and the FDA doesn't look too much into Water’s work at other sites. Don’t give the client or FDA reason to investigate by omitting that you are not trained on that instrument. 
Depending on your region, you may or may not have support from the other FSE’s (Oh Yea. We used to be called Field Service Engineer’s, but now we’re specialists so the job doesn’t require a science bachelors. Good luck with that decision, Waters. You’d be putting regular people without chemical knowledge in very dangerous settings. I hope you stick to hiring people who have science degrees).  It really sucks that they took the engineer title away from women. 
Women! The company still actively employs more male FSE’s than female. Get ready for male engineer personalities that make you prove you can do the job.  Also get ready to be applauded for being an engineer when walking into work or up to clients. Apparently they think it’s the lack of applicants keeping them from having a gender balanced work place. 
Overtime: HA! Get ready to work like a salary slave who’s offered overtime, is denied overtime even after putting in the hours, and doesn’t really get overtime. 
Agilent gives the bonus Waters took away this year AND gives overtime.

title: When will it start getting better and stop getting worse Christopher  O’Connell?
pros:
Every co-worker treats you like a friend, there with you every day trying their best and working collaboratively to research, design, develop, test, release, and support cutting edge technology.
Recently started an official remote work program.
Renewed sense of urgency within company to innovate in new areas with new ideas.
cons:
You and your co-workers arrive every day in the trenches, with poor direction and leadership from the C-suite. They tell their subordinates to tell their subordinates to tell their subordinates that they are fighting the good fight and Not to give up. Pick up your rusted tolls to work on your broken down aging equipment so that we don’t have to fall back and retreat. You and everyone else are trying to reach HQ over the radio but the radio is sparking and you never know the next time you will get shocked so you try the phone. When you try the phone it buzzes in you ear and you dial HQ but you only get a voice mail box. You continuously take incoming fire from your enemies that you can see closing in. Your company get called in by your CO and he tells you that the enemy is loosing ground and are about to surrender because of your hard work and dedication. Someone asks the CO about the new plane with the photon torpedoes, to which he replies that they are not a threat. You ask about the old radios and when they will be replaced and he does not recognize the name, model or function.
Everyone around you is frustrated because all they want to do is win. All the employees go to chow and talk about the burning desire down to their  bones to win the war. You try to strategize new ways of working with the old broken equipment to keep trying to make and support the same old equipment that has not been updated in years. All the while being given additional old equipment to support and maintain and upgrade with no additional help. Why are we still using the same process and mentality we used in the 80s and 90s?  Everyone knows they are broken, manual and restrictive.

If you like working for a company fighting a war of attrition that will end with you being payed off because of purely money driven desire to make your stakeholders happy to make your financials look better then Waters Corp is great for you.

If you like being underplayed and over worked then Waters Corp is great for you.

If you like to justify why you need modern common tech to do your daily work then waters Corp is for you.

If you like fighting with Aetna, their healthcare insurance provider to get coverage and the medication that your doctor prescribes then Waters Corp is for you.

If you like eating overpriced, unhealthy food that makes you tired and by dirty pissed off employees sub-contracted then Waters Corp is for you.

If you like a company that is only concerned with employees in Milford, MA and not any other office then waters is for you.

If you like working in a drab and depressing, halogen light area with random outages and flickering lights and crumbling buildings then Waters Corp is for you.

In software / informatics there are huge problems:

title: Messy R&D Team Management in Singapore

Most if not all promotional decisions were made to solely form a particular team structure, but not to appreciate team members' outstanding performance.

title: Great company
pros: Great organization, customer focused, great people in management.

title: Good place to work
pros: The management (at least at my location) is super sweet, understanding and clearly passionate even after dealing with the weekly thrice weekly 3 hour rushes (perks of being so close to a university). The pay is amazing, especially since I have no prior food industry experience. Though I have only been working here for 6 weeks, I still really appreciate the benefits and perks that I have experienced at Sheetz. The team that I am with is helpful and understanding that I am still learning. I also like how the uniform shirts were free, (even when I requested replacements), the food discount (50% MTO food on the clock, 10% off everything else). My regulars make the job more enjoyable since I feel like I make a personal connection, and that I made someones day at 4 am.
cons: No real cons I have experienced, specifically with the company.

title: Fine for a HS/college kid, not a career, would not repeat.
pros:
- Decent health benefits (when they started), 401k, etc. 
-Pay is decent
- Decent physical working environment (worked in a corporate setting)
- On-site cafeteria at corporate, on-site gym, on-site wellness center 
- Casual corporate dress code
- Quarterly bonuses 
- Employee outings 
- Technology worked 99.9% of the time
cons:
- Little to no training/inconsistent training 
- No review of attendance or sick policy at hire
- Was given a store handbook at hire so had nothing to follow for the corporate setting when management neglected to fill in those gaps, or the store handbook (uniform, etc.) was applicable to my job. 
- Hours different than what was told at hire, then said that would change when openings for original hours became available, which is deceitful. 
- Inconsistent schedules, constantly changing, probably cause by the high turnover.  
- Worked several holidays a year 
- Complaints that came from customers/employees were not dealt with, just handed a coupon or gift card and not addressed. This one is probably what bugged me the most. Saw many customers saying that they literally didn’t want anything free, just for the situation to be fixed, and the response was always, here’s something free, bye! 
- Felt like what I was doing was a waste of time, see above.

title: Here are some of the PROS and CONS about Sheetz. you should apply since the pros are greater than cons
pros:
- Work with incredible people
- the store is always clean
- good customers
- 50% discount if on the clock and 10% of the clock
- flexible hours (work for 4, 6, or 8 hrs)
- secret Santa during Christmas
- can work at other stores 
- I have worked in all of the stores in my district during their meetings or if they 
  needed help (we are our own community)
- Great feedback from managers
- Personal time and vacation time (I think it happens after a year but not sure)
- fast pace
- Point system to keep you motivated to work Maximum 27 points. They did 12 
   points back in the days
- New products always coming in
cons:
- There is a day when all the bad customers decide to show up and you don't 
   wanna be at the registers.
- Sometimes there are shift wars
- I wish the managers decided to send 1 person at the register for half of the shift 
  and then switch them with someone else. (this never happens unless us 
  employees decide to do half shift at the register)

title: Be careful!
pros: Most employees are friendly.  Benefits are good but same as all other employers. Fun activities if you get to take a break to enjoy them.  Worked between different departments and some are better than others and treat employees better than others.
cons: Its a good old boys club working in corporate.  You either conform to them or get pushed aside.  Cut throat internal culture of employees trying to climb the corporate ladder.  Great culture on the surface but once you realize the politics going on, you learn very quickly what you need to do to keep your status.  Who you are within the social hierachy matters more than what you do and how hard you work.  Nepotism at its finest as you must know or be related to someone to get ahead.  The company rewards employees who stay forever instead of employees who are a better match, work hard, bring new ideas.  Lacks diversity.  People are afraid to speak up about what is going on because there are limited employers in the area.

title: Stressful yet rewarding
pros:
• Competitive pay (for retail)
• Room for promotion
• Well managed aside from some personal gripes
cons:
• Shifts could be incredibly stressful. Night shifts in particular can be incredibly hellish as the store I was working for would only have three people working until 5am when the morning rush began at 4am. 

• Expect regular call offs that can occasionally go uncovered.

• Need to have full availability to get the hours you want unless you "claim" a shift as some employees were able to do. Once you do get those hours expect to be juggled across multiple shifts throughout the week. Part of me wants to chalk it up to the difficulties of scheduling, but I suspect that it could have been done in a way that better respects employees' health.

• Also expect to work every holiday. Not only that, expect at least one of your coworkers to call off on the big holidays and you will absolutely be called in to cover their shift. You can expect a bigger paycheck, though so whether or not this is a pro or a con is entirely subjective.

• If you're a bit like me, it can feel a bit like you're working for a cult.

title: Don't work there!!!!
pros: I will say there is plenty of benefits if your a favorite of the management team there. If you are not you expected to work your butt off and not enough to get a promotion. You curse one time you get fired, yet supervisors curse at you plenty of times, follows you out the store like chases you since they don't wear headsets and won't communicate with you. Unless, they chase you throughout the place. Some people can get promoted for just yelling and cursing at the supervisor yet you do it once you are automatically fired! It makes no sense they have favorite supervisors still work there that shouldn't! Managers won't do anything if you make a issue noticed, yet if you call HR nothing really stands!
cons: Everything about the company is a con, they choice the favorites and that's how it sticks.

title: Life as a Salesperson
pros:
- Schedules are very flexible (fits my college classes very well)
- Work schedules are generally 3 weeks out and allow for good planning
- Good amount of hours per week
- Good pay per hour 
- Good amount of personal and vacation hours given quarterly
cons:
- The pace can be a bit stressful to keep up and maintain (kitchen or register)
- Problems with staffing (hiring and turnover) 
- Standards enacted at district level are usually not feasible
- Mangers at store-level and onward don’t always understand processes and procedures

title: Good pay with tons of overtime, although understaffed
pros: Pay is good, Benefits, Challenging, fast-paced work, minimum of 5 hours overtime each week (45 hour weeks), and quarterly bonuses
cons: Understaffed at some points, leading to overwhelming customer flow at times, glorified fast food, call-offs can leave you with more over time as you have to cover all/some of the next shift depending on management.

title: Third Shift-Fast paced repetitive work
pros:
Decent benefits if full-time. Only dental and vision if part-time (great coverage though) 
Flexible scheduling for college students and good pay 
Good company to work for; bad coworkers with attitudes can ruin impression but this varies store to store.
cons:
Third shift gets the shaft as most employees are scheduled for first shift (second and third working with 3 employees each including the supervisor yet First had at least 8 working Monday-Friday) 
More work put on afternoon and night shift but again this all varies by store. (Example: Night supervisor to put away truck plus complete their own work and watch over the entire store so presents a potential security risk) 
Work-life balance (especially for those on Third shift) 
Labor intensive

title: It's a company on the rise
pros: Really feels like a team atmosphere. They make you feel valued, which is rare in the industry. It's challenging, but rewarding. They give bonuses, stock options. The pay is good, really good. It's busy. No sign of the recession in sight. And most days it's fun!
cons:
It can be a bit hectic. This is to be expected given the amount of business we do. I would say I wish corporate would give enough hours to schedule at least one additional person on second shift. That would go a long way to getting tasks done. 
The only other downside is the structure fluctuates a bit. In the beginning it can be a little daunting putting altogether, it takes a little while to comprehend it all. Not really a con per se, could just be more streamlined

title: Sheetz is a Spectacular Company!
pros:
Employee discount! Employees get a 10% discount on everything except gas, lottery, alcohol, milk, or eggs. They get a 50% discount on the clock for Made-to-Order items, Made-to-Go items, and Sheetz Bakery items.

Offers benefits such as medical, dental, and vision! Not to mention a 401(k) and employee stock ownership program!

You become part of a family, the Sheetz family.
cons: Face-paced and difficult to keep up with at times.

title: Good job for college student
pros: Pay is nice, and their benefits are very helpful if you work full time. Never bored because you are constantly doing something. Easy to transfer from store to store, and occasionally you will have opportunities to go help another store if they are understaffed so you get a broad understanding of how different every store is. Customers are various, but I never had any major issues. Majority of the customers are regular or overtime become regulars because you develop friendships.
cons: My biggest con is that favoritism and people who claim seniority (that are not managers) will always be rewarded more, treated better and given more opportunities.  If you are not a favorite you will never matter and what you do does not matter.

title: Depends on your store manager.
pros:
Free GED.
Paid time off.
Vacation time every year.
Quarterly bonuses.
cons: District manager will back store managers no matter what the claim, even if said claim is for cornering young women in the office and getting physical with camera proof.

title: Assistant Manager Hospitalitu
pros: Fixed schedule, great people, did I mention every fri/sat off!
cons: Frequent call outs by salespeople

title: Good place to work
pros: They are flexible with hours and will work around another job or school. There are a lot of different benefits that consist of good insurance, bonus, and employee recognition events for time worked. Good starting pay for a 'gas station' there is a decent amount of work involved but overall nothing too demanding.
cons: You max out on  raises after 3 year and if you are looking to move up in the company it can be difficult due to not many openings but it is not impossible.

title: Location, Location, Location
pros: Flexible schedule, amazing benefits/pay rates for position, overall great atmosphere and communication from a COMPANY level
cons: Some management can be TERRIBLE. I've experienced and witnessed harassment on a daily basis. Some places correct it immediately and following procedure. Other places will never resolve issues.

title: Fun fast paced job
pros: Day goes quickly and very good culture in stores with respect at the core...can easily be promoted all the way to store  manager making very good money if you are  customer focused dependable and have a good work ethic..
cons: Brand new person hired as assistant off street and tenured employee of 14 years... only thing separating them is one week vac and under 2 dollars pay...

title: Ok job
pros: -good pay & benefits & that’s about it
cons:
-being open 24/7
-work holidays
-rude customers 
-rude management. My manager was the absolute worst. she had zero compassion 
-only had two girls working the midnight shift. there were a lot of tasks to do on that shift but it was always hard to do with only two people. Didn’t feel safe working the midnight shift. 
-lottery customers were the worst 
-favoritism
-understaffed all the time on afternoon/midnight shifts. They always had at least eight people work in the morning shift & hardly anybody in the afternoons or midnights
-gave me a hard time getting time off after grandparents passed away

title: Best Job I've Ever Had
pros:
50% off Sheetz food while on the clock
10% off everything while off the clock
Mileage for traveling to other stores
Food and Drink coupons for finding out of date items
Tuition Reimbursement
3 cents off per gallon of gas
Awesome benefits
Quarterly Bonuses
Semi-Annual Raises (50 cents every 6 months)
New shirts every year (free)
Free uniforms
Awesome Store managers
Great food
Flexible hours
cons:
Frequent Call offs
Rude employees
Rude customers
Unusual hours

title: Great place to work overall
pros:
• Family oriented
• Benefits
• Fast paced (you will stay busy)
• You will learn the value of teamwork
• 50% discounts on made to order food and drinks while on the clock
• Management flexible with scheduling and enough employees to switch with if needed
cons:
• Not enough employees on 2nd and 3rd, but 6+ people on first, even though 2nd shift is just as busy, if not busier, than 1st shift. (3 people on 2nd and 3rd)
• Shift wars in some stores
• A busier than normal day/night not being taken into consideration when certain tasks are not completed

title: Excellent culture in stores; corporate culture is a let down
pros: The culture in the stores is one of family environment.  It is a great opportunity to build you career from the ground up.
cons: The corporate environment and opportunities is very challenging and you are told you are part of the family but really are treated like a number and not a person. The disconnect and visible treatment of some employees is very disheartening.  Stay at the store level and you wont be disappointed.

title: Nice place for a summer job
pros: I got a bunch of hours working night shift, my coworkers were nice and didn’t slack off, my supervisors really listened to me. I really enjoy working second shift here.
cons: When they raised the base pay to attract new employees, they didn’t raise the pay of existing employees. The manager did not listen to/follow my availability that I gave them.  When I worked third shift we were always short staffed and busy, but we didn’t get any sort of recognition or differential to make up for what we went through every night.

title: Great First Job
pros: There are opportunities to move up for those who are dedicated.
cons: The job itself is a combination of McDonald's and Speedway. In this regard, it is an awful job.

title: There’s better options out there
pros: Above minimum wage pay, Pretty good insurance and benefits, somewhat easy labor, quarterly bonuses
cons: No shift differential for night shift, more labor expectations are heaped upon you, but corporate slashed hours because they can’t afford to pay their employees, the management in my particular store is laughable and breaks under pressure

title: Decent company
pros: Quarterly bonus, in house training, yearly department celebration, very laid back.
cons: Low pay for amount of work, no recognition for those who go above and beyond, poor advancement opportunities, no discipline for poor performing techs.

title: Great cooperation
pros: Big cooperation, excel pretty quickly if you want to climb the ladder, fast paced, team work makes the dream work -
cons: Not enough people on different shifts, you get paid biweekly, training needs to be more intense, rules weren’t followed by employees and managers, favoritism between mangers and employees, work like a dog for little pay

title: Mediocre at best
pros:
Nice hourly wage in comparison w/similar jobs
Flexible schedules 
Vacation/personal times
cons: Work to pay ratio is awful, most managment is incompetent and lazy, typically a couple people on each shift do most of the work,

title: Eh; Not the best, but not the worst
pros:
Higher paying entry-level positions
Quarterly bonuses based on friendliness surveys, up to $500 per quarter for sales associates
If you need to work at another store, they will pay gas based on mileage
cons:
Dropping hours and raising prices to compensate for company-wide raises
Working full-time hours in part time position
Not having enough employees to hiring way too many
Switching up management about every 2 years; the send the Assistants to new stores

title: Great Accomodation for College Students
pros:
I can only speak for myself as a student, but Sheetz is very flexible in your hours and scheduling.  They also provide tuition for people who work at least 16 hours a week.  Work with diverse age groups and they like to create a family atmosphere at stores for their employees.

Room for advancement.
cons:
Unmotivated workers (sometimes).
Understaffed can lead to stressful shifts.

title: Great for young people and students
pros:
Very flexible for students (at least at my store)
Fun
Good company culture
Competitive wages
Always something to do
Easily pick up hours
cons:
Not all of the employees were good workers
Not everyone was trained properly- people who often worked as cashiers didn't know what to do in the kitchen
Understaffed at times

title: You're nothing but a number ...
pros: Good benefits and other employees were good to work with.
cons: Management has no regard for its employees and always demands more and more.  They tell you what they think you want to hear to keep you, but never follow through.  Always find excuses to not give you a promotion.

title: Great opportunity for a young college student
pros: Working the weekends at Sheetz got me through college. I was always impressed that Sheetz pays above minimum wage, plus I received a scholarship to help pay for my studies. The work was fair and reliable. Great job for a young person in school.
cons: Some of the customers were unbearable and downright rude. You need a tough exterior to deal with some folks.

title: A Great First Job, or even a Great Career
pros: Great pay & benefits, always looking to move you to a supervisor role if you put the work in, management was great at making me feel safe on the job (I worked night shift as a young woman in early 20's)
cons: Camera monitoring on the job by corporate (but at least they're upfront about it), difficult to leave shift if you're sick

title: It REALLY depends on your managment team
pros: The pay rate and benefits offered are good.
cons: Don't know if it's just my store in particular but there are definitely major problems with turnover and favoritism.

title: Good company benefits, terrible work-life balance
pros: Benefits... Personal days earned quarter, vacation depending on tenure, 401k, ESOP, health/dental/vision
cons: Being a 24/7 business does not allow for strong work-life balance, especially in management.  High turnover in high volume areas makes staffing difficult.

title: Awesome manager, flexible schedule, easy work
pros:
create your own schedule 
always something to do 
decent starting pay (depends on location)
cons:
can be overwhelming when busy 
frustrating when coworkers are lazy or are undertrained 
no room for personal growths or raises
raises are given on a time basis

title: Terrible
pros: Higher than average pay, Some great regular customers who became like family, free coffee
cons: Rude management, a ridiculous points system that docks employees even they can't work due to extremely dangerous road conditions, terribly understaffed for the volume of sales,  comically short breaks, hiring from outside the company instead of promoting worthy team members from within, working full time for an entire year before getting any vacation time,  shady business practices with management using employees for their personal gain on a whim and then slashing hours, management not honoring requests off, rampant favoritism...

title: Decent for an entry level job
pros: Reasonable Pay, previous manager was very willing to work with availability, and ensuring everyone gets the hours they need
cons: Lots of work, tile on concrete floors that are rough on feet, handful of rude customers, open 24/7, New manager limits employee hours regardless of need, only over night and managers have 40 hours a week.

title: Enormous workload and stress for mediocre pay
pros: I've heard the health insurance is decent.
cons: For several years, Sheetz has been gradually trimming hours (in the aggregate) to reduce staffing costs.  Unfortunately, the work that must be completed hasn't changed or has increased.  The results are constant high stress and regular failures to meet managements' (impossible) expectations.

title: Great for energetic people!
pros: Friendly work culture, room to grow, good benefits
cons: MUST be able to move at a fast pace on your feet for most of your shift. Company only allows one 20 minute break per shift.

title: Awesome Job!
pros: Everything is a pro, from the competitive wages to the free drinks and discounts at the locations. On boarding process was smooth and management is great!
cons: I haven’t found any yet.

title: LOVE IT HERE!
pros: This company truly lives up to the designation of "Top 100 Company." I love my co-workers and management really seem vested in having a great culture for their employees.
cons: There isn't much time to sit around, so if you don't like to put in the work, this isn't the place for you :)

title: Sales Associate
pros: Your coworkers become family, and even though we would be so busy, we always had fun while we worked!
cons: You would have to run the kitchen or the register by yourself depending on how much staff we had at the time, and have little help to none help regardless of how busy we were.

title: Sheetz job
pros: Easy job, nice co-workers, managers willing to work with you, 50% discount on some items while on the clock
cons: Terrible hours, inconsistent hours, (30 hours one week, 8 the next), always understaffed, customers are annoying, managers think they are better than the employees

title: Recommend to someone who enjoys customer service
pros:
Above minimum wage
tuition reimbursements
paid vacation/personal days
option for healthcare
401k benefits
cons:
Never enough help
always working weekends
expect a lot and not enough time to do it
Feels like work consumes your life

title: Good for college students
pros: Great benefits and they always worked around my class schedule
cons: The manager at my location was eventually fired but it took over three years and multiple bad reviews. Management at the store level could use more training.

title: Good luck if you take a job here
pros:
Pretty nice discount
Some people are tolerable
Many chances to move up within the company
cons:
Management is absolutely horrendous, very rude and play favorites 
Shifts are out of whack and night shift is always understaffed
Not worth the 9.50 an hour

title: Good Store, Soulless company
pros:
-work mostly keeps you busy
-good learning environment
cons:
-incredibly strict codes of attendance and attire
-out of touch executives
-low pay
-nearly impossible to save up personal days at 4 a year
-company has high distrust for workers
-hard to maintain/low pay-out bonuses($17 Christmas bonus, full bonus on only 4+ stars on customer surveys)
-forced to tolerate dangerous customers

title: Good place for a first job
pros: Good place for your first job
cons: If you prove yourself to be an asset to the team they will try to squeeze every last bit of efficiency out of you until you are burnt out and the job expectations are no longer reasonable.

title: Overall good  place to work for. Fast paced and stressful at times but overall nothing to difficult.
pros: benefits if full time, work around your schedule, frequent bonuses, opportunities to move up or transfer stores if wanted.
cons: Fast paced, hard work not always recognized, drama between co-workers, lazy employees.

title: I wish I never left!!
pros: Great incentives! They are always looking out for employees weather it’s free drinks or food from time to time.
cons: Store being open 24/7; however if you do your job correct  management will do their best to accommodate the hours you wish to work.

title: Good First Job- But way understaffed
pros:
Family atmosphere
Good pay
Good training
Good food
Bonuses
cons: Often understaffed, hectic environment, could be dangerous at times, not enough guidance at times,  Customers could be quite rude

title: Mom and Pop shop success story
pros: Benefits,  401K, awesome CEO's, cool corporate events
cons: not enough pay, wacky shifts to make sure you get your time.

title: Sheetz
pros: The benefits are awesome and premiums are reasonable. The pay is better than comparable jobs in the area.
cons: It never closes. Ever. Holidays, bad weather, doesn’t matter. There’s a good chance you’ll end up living there if people call off.

title: Nice job to have as a young man
pros: hours, pay, discounts, ok teammates.
cons: Working a few weekends to help out quickly turns into working every weekend. 5% of the customers made me want to quit on the spot.

title: Great place to work PT!
pros:
-Flexible
-Great Co-workers
-Management is understanding and great!
-Stay busy
-Plenty of opportunity to move up
-Decent pay raise every 6 mo.
cons:
-customers can be a pain
-must know the kitchen and the front/cashier

title: Good for a gas station
pros: Nice management, everyone treated fairly, they try to keep employees happy, clean facility, get paid during breaks
cons: Short breaks (20 mins), standing all day, very busy, pays 10$/ hr which isn't enough to live on.

title: A great place to work temporarily.
pros: Sheetz can be a really fun place to work, the pay is good, you can have a fun time, and there is lots of room for improvement.
cons: The benefits are very expensive and not the greatest.

title: Amazing company to work for!
pros:
Competitive pay
Endless Advancement opportunities 
Great Benefits 
Great people! Sheetz people are some of the best people you will ever meet.
cons:

title: Not perfect but better than some others. Overall a positive experience.
pros:
Challenging patients due to high acuity but most are very pleasant as are their families.  Not too many snobby rich people to deal with.
High standard of care on most units.
Health benefits are absolutely terrific.  Not too expensive either.
Pension
Union protection
Most managers I’ve worked under have been very good to me and as flexible as they were allowed to be
Overtime is usually available
Fairly user friendly EMR software (Cerner)
Nurses aren’t allowed to enter physician orders except in EXTREME emergency situations, freeing them up to do more actual nursing work
cons:
Salary is not competitive but benefits make up for it
Pension plan isn’t as good as it used to be.  New people coming in have a LONG vesting period.
Bureaucracy being a government hospital
Union, although mostly good, sometimes protects incompetent employees who would be fired elsewhere.
Upper management (above unit level) sometimes out of touch with realities of working in the trenches.  Directives come down from above and will be enforced for a while until the next big idea comes along
Hospital building has many structural problems
Broken equipment

title: Unfortunately understaffed.
pros: I love being a CNA. I lived in town. Good benefits, Nyship to be exact. Union state job Csea. Fortunate to leave with a 10 year pension. Great co-workers. I enjoyed working side by side with nurse’s getting through the shift.
cons: Understaffed, poor management and nurse’s don’t help with patient care (even if it’s their assigned patient). Weekends I ended up with 15 patients on a 30 bed floor for several years nothing changed. Vitals x2, accu-checks x2, I&O’s and of course call bells  which nurse’s don’t answer. Shift 3-11pm. Also nurse’s don’t help even if theres only one CNA on the floor.  Imagine this was second best staffed shift. Nights was always 1 cna on the floor.  Nurse overall attitude is not my patient not my problem. Everyone for themselves.

title: Stony Brook Medicine amazing benefits and  all the overtime
pros: Excessive overtime available throughout every shifts. Friendly environment. Awesome teamwork. The benefits is the biggest perk. Most importantly, it gives a sense of pride to work for an reputable hospital.

title: Excellent Hospital and Place To Work

As an employee, I feel that I am treated great respect by my coworkers and supervisors. I am happy with my salary for the work that I do and overall have a very pleasant work environment.

title: Reality of Med Device Development - Xi
pros:
Great people with plenty of technical knowledge and experience in the med device development space. This place knows how to get products developed and through the rigor of FDA approval. 
If you are looking for a competent, full service med device development firm, this company is worthy of serious consideration.

Having had worked at Ximedica for several years, I can tell you (subjectively) that management has always treated clients and employees with respect and tried to do what is best.... now that doesn’t mean that everything is perfect but it does mean that there is a genuine effort to be fair, reasonable, treat clients and employees with respect, and do what’s right (even when it is not easy). The people (management and individual resources) at Ximedica really do enjoy their work and strive to be trusted advisors to clients. My experience is that the company is full of people who want to succeed. Really great people, great drive, genuine personalities, fun environment, plenty of drive and technical excellence.
cons:
The medical device development process is not an easy one. Proper development of any medical device takes time and a considerable amount of funding, and as a result the process can be frustrating for both client and consultant.... the process is often filled with peeks and valleys. Although Ximedica utilizes their depth of experience and expertise to plan and resource projects, Ximedica cannot predict every twist and turn that may arise and as a result schedules and budgets are impacted... this is difficult and stressful for everyone.

There have been instances where resources were spread too thin and I’m sure that there have been/are instances where employees should be compensated better. I do understand that there have been employees that have been unhappy for one reason or another. Their feelings and experiences are certainly valid. However, I do not believe this is the norm.

title: Ximedica
pros:
- Flexibility to work on a wide range of programs/devices
- Fun, growing company with growth opportunities for tenacious, high energy med device professionals
- Non political environment
- Ability to wear multiple hats and get exposure to wide range of development activities from initial research and strategy all the way to pilot/small scale production
- Quite a bit of flexibility in terms of hrs, remote work, etc. - just need to get the job done
cons:
- Small company, so no place to hide if you are not producing
- Program/workload can vary, and at times a lot is asked to hit program deadlines

Only veteran salesman make a decent living because they have a large customer base they built
No employee appreciation shown
Use to be a great family company, but now they are a greedy corporation only caring about more money for the Richard family.
Come salesman aren’t responsible for upkeep of the store, so only 4-5 people are yelled at for not cleaning. 
Profit sharing private company, but it seems like only more profit for people on top.
Less and less foot traffic every year due to increased internet retailers.
They say that you can take vacation anytime, but will be frowned upon during holiday seasons. 
No family life. You work ten hour shifts and come home at 10pm. And longer if you want to make a decent living.
If you don’t hit the commission quota then you owe them money. 
When they have training in corporate office in Farmingdale. You lose a day on the sales floor with no compensation. You lose sales, spend money on gas and might have a chance to win a cheap prize. And it’s usually a PC Richard gift card. 
Slowly and slowly you see regular customers coming in less and less.
A lot of older salesman work here due to they can’t have a career change this late in their life.
If you are legitimately sick, it’s frowned up to call off work. And they will guilt trip you to come in, only to find out it’s dead all day.

For a mature company that is not the kind of tactic employees want to see.

pros: Provides Decent salary and benefits
cons:
The IT department is disproportionate in hiring American workers VS Indians from India.  Thos is blatant cronyism and is ignored by senior management.  In fact a VERY high ranking individual in IT was asked to resign in 2017 as this came to light that kickback is were being made to several well placed directors and above.  Since then the practice e went underground for awhile but still persists shoving out well deserved ing american labor.
Management in IT from top to bottom practice this unfair a d illegal hiring practice.

Front line managers are uneducated and incompetent practicing intimidation and bullying  of workers instead ofeading them.

title: Horrible Hours
pros:
Management is trying. They want to improve employee satisfaction.
Revenue is growing - always easier to be in a growing company than a shrinking company.
cons:
They have implemented a "Speed to Market" program in Product Development and Operations. They are trying to bring product to market faster by increasing the amount of communications. What it means is meetings at 7 am and 8 pm on the same day are normal, and occurring multiple times per week. And everyone's time is spent in meetings rather than completing their tasks.
Product Development and Operations is under staffed and under resourced, and management doesn't want to admit it.

title: Porch is the best company I've worked at
pros: Porch isn't for everyone. It's fast moving, dynamic, and people who work here need to be nimble because the company is comfortable and openly accepts change. Porch and leadership are very focused on driving rapid growth and it is an extremely ambitious company. It is fun to see this payoff with the company growing extremely rapidly over the last several years and from what we see, it doesn't feel like it will slow.   People are really high quality individuals at the company and consistently the company is bringing in top talent. This is the place I've been able to do my best work and it challenges me to keep raising the bar.
cons: It will be nice when the company is a bit larger and more funds can be put toward weekly lunches. I like the perks we have, but would love lunches.

title: Good environment, terrible pay, good medical benefits
pros: Great team of creative and intelligent people.   Light and airy work environment.
cons: The monetary compensation is not great.  Moreover, It seems like management always finds a way to shave some dollars off of your commission; like penalizing you %10 off your overall sales for not pitching a particular product on an unrelated call.  That is ridiculous when you consider that in 1 month you'll probably make 1 mistake that will cost you 10% of the crumbs that were making in the first place.  Moreover, I get paid less now  than I did before Porch acquired the company that I used to work for.

title: Great Coworkers, Difficult for Long Term Growth
pros:
+ The people. Porch is a company that attracts young and diverse employees, which results in an incredibly fun work environment. I've made some lifelong friends during my time at Porch
+ The location is pretty awesome - right down in SoDo near the stadiums with some great food all around
cons:
+ Work like this is typically a stop gap measure for people - build some experience and move onto bigger things. It was rare to see people promoted and elevated internally, at least when I was there. My Account Management team went through 4 managers in 1 calendar year, and all 4 were external hires. No wonder they all ended up washing out. In a customer facing role, the key to success is understanding the customer, and there were plenty of strong candidates to choose from internally
+ Management does not do a great job at listening and learning from the people in the trenches. The all-hands meetings seem a bit manufactured.

title: Pay structure  confusing
pros: I liked all the employees  who worked at Porch in Bedford
cons:
They hired me a 37 K then told me it was only 10.58 per hour. Supposedly the first 2 months of 1,200 bonus were guaranteed.   Then I waited for 3 weeks for my 1st paycheck.   it was not on direct deposit as it was supposed to be and it was only for the $10.58 per hour.  I and all the new people were told that we would not receive the 1st bonus check till Sept 2019   -  ( We were hired June 2019)
Also, it has never been in writing what you have to sell to get the bonus at all.
How many ADT  and how many Liberty Mutual that you need to sell daily/weekly or monthly.
When I received my first check and it was not what I was told, expected or what was in my contract  I  immediately emailed, text and called the man who hired me.

No one answered my calls or emails.   I was totally ignored.    When I ask about my paycheck in the office no one seemed to my supervisor that could answer my questions.

I quit that following Monday

title: Better find a part-time job as well. Selling an idea, not a real product. Call Center feeling. Laughable wage.
pros: The only star is for the employees that work here and the direct managers. Everyone is friendly and you'll make friends.
cons:
I'm speaking on behalf of the Local Market Specialist Role. The pay and compensation structure is absolutely horrendous and you are always being nickel and dimed your pay. Dissatisfied employees and the mood has changed significantly since I've been here leading to high turnover. Any person with selling experience DO NOT PERSUE, for your own good. This should only be a very basic entry level job if that. 

We are forced to sell a dream and the service is constantly changing where the customer always seems confused. You're basically trying to squeeze out pennies from most of your potential customers that end up getting mad and cancelling the service right away. No accountability from the company results in the sellers losing any kind of commission from the sale. At this point it's almost laughable. 

The higher ups are always promising that a better product is coming with no follow through. High expectations with an unrealistic strategy. 

Please do not get caught in this trap. This is not a sustainable job whatsoever.

title: Together We Win....ya right together you win and we all lose....
pros: The atmosphere and the people you get to work with....
cons:
1. NOBODY with in this company follows its "values" - the cofounder plays favorites and is EXTREMELY biased in every situation  presented.

2. They make you read a book as a management team and tell you manage along those lines: dont care take, confront one another, and blend your personal and professional life - when you confront someone, you are reprimanded for it and told to stop...yet you told us you want us to do this? -blending our personal and professional lives yet we are NOT allowed to hang out with coworkers outside of the office? Did I mention the hypocrisy?

3. They terminated over 40 employees without notice, and gave 2 hours to get our personal items and leave.

4. 1st value of Porch is "No Jerks, No Egos"....yet everyone who was promoted had an ego, and you can clearly see the ego's. 

5. The commission sucks, and they want tou to have a 4 year COLLEGE degree to do a call center position....

title: Lots of Movement and Constant Growth!
pros: Porch is growing tremendously! So if you are looking for a place where you will wear many hats and learn something new everyday, this is the place for you.
cons: With pace of how fast it growing, it’s hard to just focused solely on your job. There are a lot of position that still need to be put in place to make this ship sail successfully.

title: Industry Leading Vision and Culture
pros: The leaders exemplify the vision and values and genuinely care about their employees.  The culture is engaging, fun and challenging.  So appreciate the openness, teamwork and commitment to our our customers.
cons: None - so refreshing to be part of a team that lives the values and works each day to engage and improve.

title: Best place I've worked
pros: Growing company that has a fun, collaborative work environment. Great people who are working toward a common goal. Porch is not perfect, but the culture is second-to-none.
cons: Tough industry to maneuver, leading to a lot of changes in the organization. Need to have the ability to adapt quickly.

title: Worth it if you know what you are doing.
pros: Culture is great. You can grow outside of your role.
cons: If you are not used to change it is hard to adjust. Understanding the product and being able to adjust is a must. You need to have sales experience or the ability to learn fast.

No one stays much longer than a year if they can make that.

title: Unprofessional
pros: I loves the Location in canton GA due to the Co-Workers I had. We Were more of a family then anything!
cons: They constantly moved things around. Always lost lots of partnership. Unprofessional due to the fact, that they told everyone they had 1 hour to clear their desk and leave because they were shutting that location down! Left lots of new mothers and soon  to be mothers hanging financially ! Also before the big revile they up and fired the ones they did not want there and transferring the ones they would prefer to have at the Seattle location.

title: Career Growth? Look Elsewhere.
pros:
By far Porch hired some of Seattle’s top talent. Not just top talent, but genuinely amazing people. I will be calling many from Porch friends for life. For that I am forever grateful. 

I write this review for those that are left (most have already gone) as you deserve better, and better is out there.
cons:
The recent review stating the CEO needs an executive coach couldn’t be more accurate.  I wanted to give him the benefit of the doubt as there is no doubt he’s under stress with the current trajectory of the company, but he was the iceberg that struck the Titanic. Additionally, I’ve unfortunately seen him go through 3 EA’s during my time - each one I’ve repeatedly heard he has berated and made cry on multiple occasions. We get it, you’re stressed but taking it out on your team and not hiring real HR to clean up the toxic culture you allow is shady (and most of your employees think you’re an anti-social jerk).

The same can be said for *most* of the leadership team, which happens to be the water that is sinking the ship. Minimal transparency and lack of real care for the underpaid individuals who work their tails off to keep the place running. There are some great mangers, but they have no support to make things right and are doing their job with both hands tied behind their back. The 3+ years I worked at Porch was a continual revolving door with multiple stressful layoffs and people jumping ship. 

As much as I love some of the sales team members, the culture is like watching reruns of “Workaholics”. Caffeine pill bottles, frequent vape breaks, put-put golf down every aisle and bad EDM/Rap music playing loudly ALL DAY LONG so all prospects and customers can undoubtedly hear. In their defense, it may be necessary to sell the product (the product is a mess in case you were wondering).

Long story short - if you want a career, competitive (respectable) pay, purpose in your role and mentorship, I would recommend taking full advantage of Seattle’s booming job market and avoid Porch. 

Leaving was bittersweet due to the amazing people I worked with, but getting out of those old brick walls showed me the INCREDIBLE opportunities that are out there. Porch taught me I deserve better. And I truly thank them for that.

title: Bad environment, horrible organization!
pros: Beer Friday’s, benefits. PTO.
cons: Management, class pets, no HR, no company values, scams, etc.

title: Put profits before people.
pros: Many people do “care deeply”, a core company value.
cons: CEO doesn’t care deeply about his employees, just the bottom line. He’s aggressive to the point of being very off putting, questionable ethics, and reactive. Many good people leave because they’re underpaid.

title: Looking bleak
pros: Location is good, people are easy going.
cons: Pay is pretty awful.

title: Not Recommended
pros: The schedule is fair, laid back environment, no dress code.
cons: No transparency regarding pay, only promotes favorites, management does not assist reps, management is untrustworthy.

title: Lots of Brush Offs
pros: You get to work from Home
cons: Everchanging and no flexibility on schedules

title: I love this place.
pros: $14 start pay. Raises every year. Ten hour days go fast, my supervisor is so nice to me and so is the other management and HR dept. 2 ten min breaks, paid lunch at 20 mins and if the temp in the building is 90 or above we get 10 mins added on to each break. No dress code. No steal toe boots. Can have one headphone in to listen to whatever you want. People are nice, I keep to myself tho. I really love this place.
