Costco takes a kick back of the 401k fees but will not disclose how much. 401k fees are high.  Vacation time is only 2 weeks for first five years. However management gives some new hires more vacation time, a totally undocumented and unfair practice. Base benefits are not applied to all employees equally. There are no stock awards or ESPP. There are no bonuses. The work space consists of low cubicle walls with 4-6 people squished into a cube. There is no place to park, unless you have been here 20 years then you are gifted a reserved space. Telecommuting is not permitted. Promotions are based on who you know not qualifications. If you did not work on the business side or been here long enough to fail upward,  it's almost impossible to get into management. It's a sexist environment, which management seems clueless about. Complaints about this go nowhere. The opinions of  vendors or consultants are taken over the  skilled IT employees. Much time is wasted as people just BS during meetings and pretty much the rest of the day. Generally unprofessional environment, no one is prepared, no one is accountable, no one has a plan.

title: Good place to work through college
pros: Costco works with your school schedule and always pays above minimum wage. We get benefits and even a big frozen turkey during Thanksgiving.
cons: For the first few years you'll have to close aka getting home at like 11pm every night. Customers will abuse you constantly so if you don't like being yelled and swore at, it's not the job for you.

title: Loved it
pros:
-great benefits, even for part time
- very organized 
-people were amazing to work with
-got a good amount of hours
-college retention program was amazing because I was able to take months off for school and come back to work seamlessly
cons:
-taxing on your body due to standing for hours and running around the store
-store stock and arrangement changes every day so it is hard to know where anything is
-sometimes hard to get work off

title: Uncooperative management, good benefits
pros: Good benefits, consistent raises, other employees are usually great but that can be very hit or miss
cons: Management does not work with all employees to train for other departments, nor are they cooperative with advancement (as much as they might say they are). They also will not allow at-home agents because they don’t want to ruin their “Costco culture” which is non existent and a completely missed opportunity.

title: Amazing
pros: Loved working here. Could be part time, full time, or make it a career! Great pay, great benefits, great everything!!!
cons: Depending on the warehouse, people can be click-y. And if it’s a union building, people tend to act entitled (not fun to work with).

title: Set the bar high, but the few cons really outweighed the pros.
pros: Good work, high standards, and amazing benefits.
cons: Rough hours, especially the graveyard shifts. Grueling physically at times, it’s hit or miss with some of the employees you have to work with. Strict rules and standards, which isn’t a bad thing, but it takes some getting used to.

title: Great place to work if you don’t mind working retail hours
pros:
Great pay
Lots of paid time off (earned after many years of service)
Great benefits
cons:
Have to work weekends
Sometimes have to work closing shifts until 10 pm
Not a great place to work if you’re a single parent

title: Counts merchandise, Fixes inventory, audits mistakes, and files claims
pros: I come in, do my daily tasks, and then leave. It is not that stressful as long as you do your work.
cons: I start work at 4am, management wants daily reports of counts and constantly asks you questions, and you have to be on top of what you do.  It feels like a leadership role, employees and management look for you for leadership & answers, but you are not paid enough for this burden.

title: Not bad far from the worst
pros: Free executive membership. Time and half on Sunday.
cons: No flexible schedule, you are either early morning or evenings, you occasionally get a Saturday or Sunday off but not both days, it is slow and boring at times. Mostly busy work and management is hard to talk to as they always moving like they are busy.

title: decorator turned supervisor turned pt baker, all because of seniority
pros: I love our gm. The whole warehouse gives a very family like feel.
cons: business is business. it doesn't matter if you try to make a difference. it only matters if you do your job, punch in and punch out.

title: For what the job is, there is nothing better.
pros:
- great pay with steady, predictable raises
- great benefits, even for part time employees
- good amount of vacation time
- good sick call policy
cons:
- really the only downside is the job itself, retail is retail. Some people just suck to deal with but you are making good money doing it.
- because of the excellent pay for retail work, the standards put on even the lowest employees are very high, relatively speaking.

title: Great Pay and Benefits. Super Repetitive and Demanding.
pros: Great coworkers, great pay, and you get benefits
cons: Repetitive, must work on the weekends, and no privacy

title: Poor Management, Great Company
pros:
-Good Pay 
-Bonus
-Holidays
-Reasonable Perosnal Time
-Amazing Benefits
cons:
-To many poor management  choices 
  Managers need a serious improvement on people skills on leading by example 

-Too much gossip between higher ups about employees were others can hear them, zero courtesy for many private matters.

title: Excellent employer
pros: Great health and 401k Benefits and vacation. Ability to move within the company or warehouse.  Internal training provided for skilled positions which can transfer outside the company.
cons: For those working part time and possibly working somewhere else, Costco expects to be first priority. That can be difficult.

title: Work life balance
pros:
I worked for Costco e-commerce group 

- Work life balance is really good
- Less stress at work 
- Opportunity to learn but no growth 
- Job security is good
cons:
- Very low Salary compared to market 
- Not much flexibility at work 
- No work from home policy 
- No bonus or stock
- Not good benefits

title: Great benefits, environment
pros:
- Costco benefits are the best I've ever seen. Medical,  pharmacy, dental insurance with low copays. Free eyeglasses every year depending on the amount. Heading aids big discount! (Which I wear) 
- free samples
cons: - need more teamwork in the pharmacy instead of one to two person working while everybody else chit chats.

title: Great place to work, but not to pair with school or other commitments
pros: Great pay, free membership (Basic for during evaluation, Executive afterwards), flexible hours, and friendly and supportive coworkers (mostly).
cons: Not a job to juggle with outside commitments (full-time student, second job, etc.),  strict dress code (be prepared to buy many collar shirts and jeans), and working weekends and holidays is a must (especially starting out).

title: Ruined my life.
pros: There are none. I spent most of my working life with this company only to be thrown away like a piece of garbage.
cons:
Be very careful trusting management of Costco. Costco  has no trouble breaking the law and then hiring expensive legal representation to defend their actions.
Years of service means nothing to them. 
27 years of service meant NOTHING. 
And yes I said TWENTY SEVEN YEARS OF SERVICE.

title: Basic manual labor work
pros: Pay is decent. Some co-workers are good people. Being in-doors is a plus. Costco is a great place to shop and eat at when not working, so nice to be nearby.
cons: Supervisors are unconcerned about individual employees. Fast work pace demanded. Lack of job perks. Temporary employees often don’t get hired during my time in 2018

title: Great pay, but uncaring management
pros: As far a retail positions go, the pay here is probably among the highest to be found.
cons: Depending on the department, it can be impossible to get a consistent schedule because certain managers just do not pay attention or seem to care. Sexual harassment claims between employees are met with non-disclosure agreements and nothing ever seems to be done even when multiple people have brought complaints against one person.

title: Good job - expect to work hard
pros:
Great pay and benefits with raises every 6 months of full-time work or the equivalent in hours if part time. 
Many opportunities to try out different jobs within the warehouse.
cons:
You will be expected to work hard. Costco pays well and expects its employees to be of higher caliber than the average. 
If you're good at a particular job, expect to do it a lot.

title: Hard work but comapny will take care of you
pros: Benefits, pay wage, paid time off and holidays, Sundays are over time pay, coworkers become family, if you work hard you can transfer to different positions within the store.
cons: Every warehouse will run different as they each have their own goals so you may have a better experience at one place versus another. Hours and work can get brutal as holiday season approaches.

title: Great place to work!
pros: Starting pay is $15. Part time benefits offered.
cons: Pay scale is by hours worked. You may work 2-3 times harder than some people at the top of the pay scale and they will still make almost double what you do.

title: Great Company but depends on who is in charge
pros:
• Insurance Benefits
• Enjoy serving members
• Starting Pay is Competitive
cons:
• Management does not communicate!!!!
• Given different duties, then changed
• Sometimes you feel like you are last to know
• Time Clock Nazi's

title: Great employer, friendly coworkers
pros: Good pay, good benefits, fair raises, paid sick/personal time, paid vacation
cons: Sometimes seniority is not taken into account and  you are treated as if you have just been hired

title: Great Pay and Benefits when you start
pros: Pay is great (starting at 15.00 an hour. The work environment is generally friendly and coworkers are helpful when requested.
cons: Hours for hourly employees starting out can be erratic in the beginning.

title: Very Fast Face and fun.
pros: Fast pace, hard working, fun job.  They have good raises once to twice a year, depending on your hours.  Good benefits.  Good company with quality products and they believe in taking care of good and hard working employees.
cons: Very physically demanding.   They want face pace and to always push your limits to become a more efficient employee.

title: Not a career but solid job
pros: Great people to work with. Can turn into long term employment with excellent benefits but be aware not all management are suitable managers.
cons: Inconsistent schedule, promotions are seniority based. Better off not becoming a supervisor or manager just work enough years and one will earn good pay based on time completed.

title: Best retailer you can work for
pros: Great starting hourly. Great pay raise structure. Great benefits. Pay + Time x1.5 on Sundays. Great 401K
cons: Hard, fast paced work but worth it if retail is the route you choose.

title: Good Seasonal Job
pros: Good pay, lots of walking excercise.
cons: Management plays favorites. Tell you to work your behind off, don't call in etc and you will get hired permanently after the seasonal period. Permanent regular employees treat seasonal employees like they are better than the seasonal person.

title: Honest Costco Review
pros: Sunday is time and a half, paid holidays, and sick accumulates based on hours worked (100 hours = about 4 hours of sick pay).
cons: Micromanagement, lazy coworkers, no reward for effort, no protection/support over fellow employees, and takes advantage over youth employees.

title: Why the 5 stars?
pros: Job security because no one will get fired or demoted for being a mediocre employee
cons:
Pay
Management
Maternity leave 
Time off

title: Repetitive
pros: Great atmosphere, enjoyable management and coworkers.
cons:
"you got time to lean, you got time to clean" Don't get caught doing nothing.
All positions are repetitive, and done the "Costco Way"

title: Great place to work
pros:
-Great pay, benefits
-Raises based on hours worked, high cap
-Bonuses after a certain amount of years worked
cons:
-Hours are near full-time during holidays, but cut drastically down after Jan 1st (37hr/wk to 24hr/wk), meaning you will probably need a second PT job until April/May
-Due to this, busy days can be harder on employees due to less hours allowed/less workers on the clock

title: Good Company to Work for, Especially for Retail Employees
pros: Pay and benefits are so much better than any other major retailer. Part-time employees get benefits that are nearly as good as those for full-time employees.
cons: Since nearly all compensation is based on years of service, there are few rewards for merit. Costco is lacking in training and development and just about all levels.

title: My Favorite Place In The World
pros: They take great care of their employees, customers, and vendors. You feel protected by your rights. Plus they give great opportunities.
cons: It's tough work. Not everyone is as happy working there as I was.

title: Genuinely one of the best jobs I've ever had.
pros: Costco is a stupendous company to work for. They're fiercely loyal to their employee's and are far more than accommodating when it comes to perks and benefits.
cons: There were no cons to working for Costco. How can you beat paid holidays off, time and a half on Sunday and all the health benefits?

title: Decent Work Place
pros: Work/life balance, collaboration, friendly work environment
cons: For some work/life balance means doing as little work as possible while others feel the need to over compensate to work done for those not doing their job.  At times management is clueless but they also let you get your job done without a lot of interference.

title: Great benefits, poor management, and horrible promotions
pros: Great benefits, decent pay, and a lot of locations to move around, if needed.
cons: Promotions are hard to come by. Promotions are given based on how you display numbers to managers not hard work or college degrees(s). Education means nothing to Costco. Best way to get promoted is to move around and not stay at one location.

title: A great company to work for
pros: Great benefits, lots of opportunities to cross train, open door policy.  Costco takes care of their employees. I really enjoy working here.
cons: Standing for long hours can be hard on the body even though you get breaks and a 30 minute lunch depending on the number of hours you work.

title: Great Place, Terrible management
pros: Great pay, pay and a half on Sundays, all holiday’s off. Great benefits
cons: Terrible management, treats you as less than a person, rude, not allowed to speak to any coworkers, writeups given 2 days late with no notice

title: Great pay and benefits! But a lot of work.
pros: Everyone works very hard and efficiently for the most part. Coworkers become like family and the pay and benefits are good.
cons: The work-life balance is not good. Be prepared to work every Saturday forever. But that is the nature of retail.

title: An excellent place to work, with good people
pros: There were plenty of opportunities to learn new things, often being able to work in several different departments in a day.
cons: You could be scheduled in any department you were trained in, or your schedule could change dramatically. Management would typically consult you beforehand, so it was not much of an issue.

title: Pretty Great!
pros: Hours are amazing as a part timer with another full time job.
cons: I don't really care for the 'reviews'. They are simply copy and paste templates. You are always told to have more 'sense of urgency' but that just seems like something they tell everyone... not very personalized reviews.

title: Member Service Agent
pros: Great benefits, great team members
cons: Management doesn't help, call center morale is low, they bully you in there.

title: Go Home!
pros: Got to meet new people everyday.  Hours were good.
cons: If I sold out of product, and that's A LOT of product, instead of being paid for the hours I was scheduled to work, or given a bonus, I was just told to go home.  I felt like I was being disciplined for doing an exceptional job.

title: Costco Manager
pros:
Job security 
Health insurance 
Really no other pros
cons:
100% Politics. If you’re not a manager or above you don’t have any say! 

If you want to move up you need to play 100%politics. It doesn’t matter how qualified you are, management don’t like you won’t moved up at all!

title: Overall great company
pros: Benefits (health, vision, dental, 401k, etc...), paid paternity and maternity, PTO, some paid holidays. You have a great opportunity to build a great team environment.
cons: It’s retail. You will work nights, holidays, and weekends. Your schedule will differ week to week. You will have to relocate to be promoted.

title: I'd say your lucky if you get to work here!
pros: Better benefits than probably anyone you'll ever meet or know. Higher hourly wage than almost anyone you'll meet. Oh they have a college degree? Guess what. I make more at costco.
cons: I don't know? I scan groceries for a living?

title: Great company if you love retail
pros:
Teamwork atmosphere 
Room to grow and develop 
Opportunities within the company 
Work around  schedules if you have appointments
Great benefits and pay for part time and full time
cons:
Work weekends 
You only get the holiday off for example Christmas unless your normal off days fall on Christmas you just get Christmas off

title: 19 years with 9 years of Supervisor experience.
pros: I love the Company, opportunity to move and move-up with-in and Pay.
cons: No real cons, has same issues as other places with employees who don’t want to work for their pay.

title: Fun job, but for part-time staff you had to be there 5 days a week
pros: fun environment, and you get a membership while you work there
cons: required to be at the warehouse 5 times a week even though I was part time.

title: Good money Bad Seasonal
pros:
It was good money for being seasonal
Tons of hours for being seasonal
cons: They will let you go when ever they fill like it. Or you would just not work for a week and then they will call you to work two days and then not work for two weeks

title: Good pay, excellent benefits
pros: 92% employer-paid healthcare coverage, excellent benefits, strong (401)k employer match (up to 9% AGI), bi-annual bonuses, generous vacation accrual.
cons: Lack of promotion opportunities unless willing to relocate. Nominal educational reimbursement. Experience not properly valued.

title: Ehh
pros: Good pay with good benefits and plenty of raises if you rack up some years with Costco
cons: Depending on which location youre at and what Department youre in, life can be hell. Everything is based on seniority but alot of favoritsm too

title: Great company
pros: Excellent benefits. Paid time off, raise at least once a year. Company takes very good care if us.
cons: Building managers. While the company is good to us the moral of store depends on GM.  Ours is ruining the moral at my building.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Pay and benefits are great. Even part time workers get them. People I worked with were awesome. Not working there anymore, but I miss the people and benefits most.
cons: Closing shifts sucks because it's ran on a skeleton crew, but each Costco may be differently. Hard to get into corporate.

title: Great company!
pros: Incredible benefits,  pay is decent, fast paced environment, friendly staff.
cons: Ability to grow within the company is limited. No training so you have to rely on coworkers to give you direction. Sink or swim, the choice is yours.

title: Hard work for a great company
pros: The people and benefits are amazing. The pay is above what other companies give for the same type of work.
cons: Difficult to move upwards due to lack of opportunities without wanting to relocate.

title: Night Stocker
pros: It is a convenient work hours.  I live near by.  I am strong and healthy for the job.
cons: I never worked for Costco before.  This will be my first Night Stocker job.

title: Managers have clear favorites. Working hard will not make you a favorite.
pros: Would be nice to shop there if you could afford it on the salary.
cons: Wrangling baskets in the heat, rain, and snow for the first year, and beyond.  The weather  is a breeze in comparison to the corrupt management.

title: Sucks for Newbies
pros:
Benefits
Time and a half on Sundays 
Stable
cons:
Seniority is everything, so if you’re just starting out, you’re treated pretty bad.
Have to stay late (even after supervisors leave)
Rude members
Management is always shifting so managers can be hit or miss

title: Good if you ignore safety violations
pros: The culture was good if you wanted to stay there for 10 years.
cons: Really fast-paced during your probationary period.  They ignore the 40 pound weight limits per person for loading big items into customer vehicles.  Once was told to lift a 400 lb tree with 3 people into a pickup.

title: Membership assistant
pros:
Good pay with regular raises based on hours worked. 
Great benefits!
Free membership including extra 3 for family/friends. 
Lots of departments to move around in. 
Opportunities for growth.
cons:
Management needs improvement. (Varies between warehouse.) 
Managers sometimes treat employees unfairly. 
If member complains about employee but employee was in the right, management still blames employee.

title: Solid pay good work great benefits
pros: Benefits are great. Dental, vision, medical, all a plus. Sunday premium pay gets you time and a half per hour. Employees are friendly.
cons: Slightly understaffed so starting in carts or food court means you will be there for a while. A lot of hours, almost takes over your life.

title: Pros and cons of working for Costco
pros: Costco offers some great benefits which includes medical,  vision,  dental, free membership,
cons: When hired they only hire part- time.  It takes a long time to become full time.

title: Great Company and Culture
pros: Ive had a good experience with the management here. They generally seem to be very professional and focused on supporting their employees.
cons: Although the pay is somewhat competitive for the industry during the slow times of the year you are pressured to take vacation or sick time to deflate payroll expenses.

title: Great company with great benefits
pros: Paid vacation health benefits union in some locations. Great culture of people to work with
cons: Sometimes management can try to abuse their power. Also the job becomes repetitive after a while and if your not looking to become manager, it can be depressing.

title: Best in Retail but Terrible Management
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Paid time off.
cons: Manage by intimidation approach.  Setup for failure on a daily basis.  Demand that you display a healthy state of panic at all times while working.

title: They take good care of you.
pros: Costco has great benefits, 401k, and they pay well, the CEO likes to know they employees are taken care of and happy. It's the best retail job you could ever dream of.
cons:
Lack of communication from managers to supervisors to everyone else. 
It's retail... 
Some managers pull favoritism.

title: Merch
pros: Pay is great and benefits are better. Company constantly upgrading living wages.
cons: Management become a good ole boy system. Popularity matters and the longer people are there the less they try and care because they have put in there time.

title: Great  Company
pros: Competitive  wages, busy work environment.
cons: Management is  very unprofessional, regarding promoting freinds,family ETC . Things aren't rewarded  by your  merits.

title: Culture and pay
pros: The culture is good, however can be dependent on type of management you have.  Also the pay is decent, can make upwards of $50,000 in 2-5 years.
cons: Job is fast paced, and rarely get weekends off.  Also when you first start, all you do is close until 11pm

title: Great benefits and pay for retail
pros: Ive learned a lot at this company and the pay and benefits I received are amazing for working in a retail setting. Room for growth.
cons: Can be very stressful environment and sometimes you are left to deal with problems on your own.

title: Supes through managers are NARCISISTS
pros:
Pay is ok

$1.5 hot dog combo is still $1.5
cons:
You are dealing with narcisists who could care less about safety or the well being of employees. 

They only promote those who are "pets"

They will switch your department without any prior notice, knowledge, or opinions.

Retaliation and bullying is accepted and even rewarded by upper management

Time off is never approved.

Things were much better at costco 5-10 years ago.

I wouldn't start working here today.
job: They Change My Department Every Few Weeks

title: Costco is a great company that is focused on doing right by their employees. They have amazing benefits and pay.
pros: The best things about Costco is the insurance and career growth. They only promote within and are great with career development.
cons: Scheduling can be difficult sometimes.

title: Good and bad
pros: The people are mostly great and there’s not a lot of stress to take home.
cons: With capped salaries and salaried people being moved to hourly status, there’s a lot of frustration right now. There’s some flexibility in one’s schedule, but no working from home. It feels old-fashioned in many ways.

title: I highly recommend working for Costco
pros: Family atmosphere, good pay, excellent time off.
cons: Some of the managers could have been more supportive and committed to Costco’s mission.

title: Great lifelong job opportunities
pros: Unmatched pay for the work, rewards hard work with promotions
cons: Busy times are BUSY, if you are working in one of the stores you will be expected to work weekends which is when most of the business occurs

title: Excellent Environment to work in!
pros: Benefits including medical, dental, life insurance even as a part-time employee, flexible scheduling for students, and guaranteed minimum 25 hours  week of work including time and a half pay for everyone every Sunday.
cons: Can be difficult to get time off, many block out dates

title: A pretty decent place to work
pros:
Great Benefits/ flexible hours/ exceptional training procedures/
generous bonuses
cons: Only that they didn't ask me to return after my temp position there had expired

title: Depends on the individual warehouse
pros: Great pay, great benefits, good coworkers, free membership, flexible scheduling
cons: Whether or not you have a positive experience VERY MUCH depends on the individual warehouse and their management style. I’ve worked at wonderful warehouses with wonderful people and I’ve had to work in really not fun buildings.

title: 10/10 recommend working at Costco!
pros: Management was very supportive and lenient on our temporary worker schedules, compensation was $2.50 higher than minimum wage at the time, and they even give great benefit packages to short term employees!
cons: Sometimes the Kirkland weather made pushing carts outdoors a bit of a task

title: Public's veiw is wrong
pros: Pay is good and benefits are as well.
cons: The manager's. The work environment, there ideals and goals.

title: Used to be good...
pros: Love most of the people I work with, the pay is great, job itself is not difficult.
cons:
They run all the good employees and managers out.
They don’t have a “open door” policy,

title: Best company, great values
pros: The pay at Costco can not be beat. Also giving full benefits to part time employees and having them be affordable was amazing
cons: No real issues, some seemed to have a bit more pull in getting advanced in the company.

title: Don’t believe the hype, not a great place to work once you’re hired.
pros: $15 an hour starting pay.
cons: Favoritism and nepotism within the workforce. Some employees will make stuff up about their coworkers and rat them out to the management just to climb the ladder and the management look at everyone as numbers and not people. The work is unrewarding and dull as well.

title: Fairly good, was a cart handler paid $13 an hour but hard work for carts.

cons: Teamwork isn't always the best, work alone on carts, outside all day, only a strap to use to round up, very busy parking lot.

title: Great company, mostly for hourly employees.
pros: Great pay and benefits. High employee satisfaction. Always opportunities to move up.
cons: Salary employees tend to work well beyond the stated 45 hour per week schedule. So the extra pay sometimes doesn’t seem worth the amount of work.

title: if you get in stay in

lots of hours if you're willing to do the jobs others wont 
consistent raises about every 6 months if you're full time
cons: like all retail holidays are the worst part split days off and dealing with angry people

title: Wonderful! I couldn't imagine what my career would be like without the training they provide.

title: Great company to work for!

title: Cashier Assistant

cons: Tricky to manage school schedule at first, but once you work there for some time they are willing to work around your schedule.

title: Great for students
pros: Great pay. Starts at 13 and for a cashier you can go as high as 26 I believe. Lots of opportunity for movement and growth if you do your time. Also there is a feast every inventory day. And they will pay for your course and week of work to become a level 2 first aid attendant. Also everyone is super polite to eachother, and you will have friends from every corner of the building and every step of management.
cons: There's a sizeable handful of morons that really mess up your work, but somehow do not manage to get fired. Truly destructive morons. Difficult to take time off most times of the year until you've been there for 10. You also get to deal with the public, and will rarely be backed up by supervisors. If someone started the day before you did, they will be able to get anything they want because they've been there longer. Seniority is valued over everything, and half the people there were working there before you were born if you're young ish. It feels like it's almost expected to do people a lot of favors that go way beyond your jobs responsibilities.

title: Good experience for a first time job
pros:
- paid lunches if you work 5 hours or less
- great atmosphere 
- management is very friendly and willing to help
- double time & a half pay on select holidays
- able to cross train in different departments
- double time pay on Sunday’s
- free membership
cons:
- overworked
- applying to a different department is difficult as you can only move departments if you internally apply for a different position
- applying for an internal position can be a hit or miss. If someone also applies for that same position and have been at Costco longer than you, they’d be given the position first
- managers expect so much out of you
- understaffed and overstaffed 
- if front end is understaffed, they take other employees from other departments to help out, which could be for a few minutes or for the remainder of their shift
- depending on your department, you’ll either leave early or leave close to 12am
- some members feel entitled 
- shifts may vary from 4hrs to 8+
- sometimes managers don’t communicate properly and efficiently on what they want
- working every single weekend
- no actual discount
- some managers really push for wearing steel toes but don’t call out every single person who doesn’t wear them

title: merchandiser
pros: Indoor, music, location, shopping experience while working, get to help semi respectable customers, cafeteria is satisfying, get extra patience by dealing with irresponsible management.
cons: Management is two faced. They favour employees and take advantage of others. They even go to the extent to tell me I don't get a break today because I didn't go for break when that specific employee wanted which is contradicting to what was said by senior staff to take the break whenever. They do this contradicting words repeatedly to take advantage of new employees. There motto is "just keep moving while you are signed in at work." Which doesn't make sense based on productivity to wages. Yet senior staff are good at casually slacking off looking like they're working just because they are moving. When in fact they are talking to other staff about their holidays. Yet alone they ask for favours from "junior" employees to leave their section of employment to help them. They are manipulative! corruption in process! Costco has gone down hill, their reputation is tainted.

title: Not a good experience
pros:
* Generally good colleagues
* Salary's more or less what you'd expect for what it is
* Hard work
* Solid experience in customer service
cons:
I was hired as a Cashier's Assistant; however I was doing this maybe 20% of the time, the remaining 80% they will shift you around various duties that you didn't sign up for, knowing that you are part-time and therefore expendable means management can basically put you onto anything they like, because if you say no then its bye bye.

The environment is generally quite negative, quite a few people looking forward to leaving which is not surprising given that your breaks are counted to the last second.

I've worked in retail a few times and this was by far the most unpleasant.

title: Amazing for students
pros: I was apart of the CSRP Program (Costco Student Retention Program). Very good program that is accommodating to students. Only required to work weekends, give time off when asked for exams and etc and get close to full time hours during the winter and summer breaks. I worked mostly on carts and it was independent for the most part and a good workout. Good co workers that make it fun.
cons: Some of the management think they are really superior with supervisors telling you one thing and managers telling you another. Can get very busy (as expected) and just like any other retail, rude customers. Be prepared to work and not have perfect management.

title: Job security
pros: Security, benefit package, pension plan, stocks.  Able to transfer between locations.
cons:
All sinority based-difficult to get certain time off if someone has requested it who has more sinority.  Makes you feel trapped and unable to leave due to losing spot with sinority.
Work every weekend (either Sat or Sun) unless you have vacation planned.
Small work space shared with other employees.
No special recognition given for being top sales etc.
Not much that can be done if you have a bad manager.
Very difficult for mothers with young children to work around the schedule.
Should try to donate more items as opposed to throwing into compactor.

title: Costco Warehouse Experience
pros:
Stable hours if you were in the merchandise department, either AM or PM everyday.
They do promote within.
Part time hours for anyone doing something other than Costco.
cons:
You'd most likely work weekends quite often.
Poor management.
Pay is poor for what you do until you reach Assistant Warehouse Manager.
If you're good at your job you'll be handed more responsibilities that certain positions should have. Quite often you'll be dependent by other Managers.
Quite often you'll see everyone's morale just depletes the longer they stay there.

title: Bakery Wrapper
pros:
- Very accommodating of my school schedule, allowing me to work evenings and weekends.
- Open door policy allows for easy communication between employees and management
- Good company culture to keep employees engaged and happy
- Paid holidays, $4/hr bonus on Sundays and great benefits
cons:
- Managers can be tough and very demanding; expect you to prioritize your work life over everything else
- Overwhelming amount of work for bakery employees
- No weekends off unless you are a full time employee
- Store was  overly busy at all hours, especially weekends

title: Slave for peanuts
pros: Pt employees get 60% coverage on benefits.  That’s a pro I guess.
cons: They work you way too hard for what they pay.  Yeah above minimum wage ... but really?  You can’t survive on $15/hr comfortably.  You get a $1/per hr raise after 1200 hours.  If you’re PT it takes forever.  And people have waited years to get FT jobs.  For a company that brags about its profits they sure don’t pass it down to the hard workers. .

title: Disappointed
pros: Nice to have a free membership.
cons: I’m very disappointed with how my time working there went. I was so excited when they hired me on, I wanted to grow and have it be my forever job. In my orientation I was told after 6 months I could ask to be moved to a different section. Working in the food court was difficult. Not only was the work hard but most of the employees are so rude to each other. One went as far as asking me why I work if I’m First Nations as we get everything paid for. I kept my mouth shut because I was a new employee and didn’t want to start anything. I’m a friendly person and try to be nice to everyone but 4 months in that proved to be a mistake. They made me sign a confidentiality agreement so I can’t say much except an employee who works all around the store started making very inappropriate and creepy comments that made me worry for my safety. I new I had to report it to management. After 3 weeks of “investigating” the solution was that they told him he wasn’t allowed to talk to me anymore and I  was just supposed to accept that. I brought up being transferred to a different store and they told me that would mean they failed and couldn’t have that. By the end I felt like I had nothing to work towards there. My only option was to trust that because they had spoken to the man who threatened me I should feel safe. I didn’t. My last day I went into the lunch room and the man was there. I was going to eat lunch in my car but I couldn’t bring myself to come back to work. I called the management to let them know. They said someone would follow up with me. It’s been 2 weeks and no one has.

title: Member Service Assistant
pros: If you're a student, or 50+ years or older, this would be an ideal job for you.  Flexible hours. No difficult task. Anyone can learn the whole procedure within a week.
cons: There is no supervisor in this department. In other words, daily scheduling for employees is a never-ending issue. Getting to deal with stupid and ignorant people at the door can be a big challenge as well.

title: Managers outs for selves ..
pros: Good rate of pay . And benefits throughout employment
cons: Managers are not people orientated . Not willing to listen to points of view   just do this no reasons why so you can learn from it

title: Part Time
pros:
Good Benefits
Great Pay for individuals with little education outside of a high school diploma
Good amount of hours (guaranteed at least 25 hours as a part timer)
cons:
Schedule constantly being changed without notice
Management very resistant to change or suggestions
Location being understaffed on busy days of the week, resulting in very late breaks

title: Great long-term potential
pros: Guaranteed minimum hours for part-time employees, benefits, steady wage increases, some opportunity to move up, great long-term potential for a fair paying job.
cons: HR does not keep anything confidential which makes office politics awful, lots of employees have taken stress leave, most of the members are great but some can be challenging to deal with, difficult to move up unless you're really well liked or know someone.

title: okay - but not amazing
pros: part-time benefits, vacation, fast working environment,
cons: 1 week schedule, expected to purchase items on your day off, only 1 day off during the week.  increase in pay by $1 every 2 years

title: Very pro worker,  with lots of support
pros:
Good pay considering the education requirements
Management tends to leave you be as long as there are no problems
Free membership
Always lots to do if bored
Fairly extensive benefits
Flexible positions(great for students)
Everyone is friendly

cons:

Promotions are largely based on seniority instead of qualifications

title: Horrible Management
pros:
Good pay and benefits
Good culture values but it’s gotten lost
cons: Management have no idea just delegate ,micromanage, Disgustingly unorganised, constantly understaffed while management in the office gossip, Or worrying about who they going to counsel for not enough mater donations to make employees life miserable

title: Depends on Location
pros: Depending on the location people can be great to work with and you really get a sense that you are part of a community working towards a common goal.
cons: If it's a bad location the employee's get away with anything and everything and if you try to discipline them management may or may not back you up. If they do they very rarely follow up.

title: fun, friendly, painfull
pros: amazing pay, friendly staff and management, fast paced
cons: heavy lifting, long hours standing, rude customers, possible injuries

title: Great place to work, pays well and good people
pros: Relaxed and fun working environment
cons: Very old school, requires in office work 8 - 5 Monday to Friday with little to no flexibility, no option for any learning, low budget so you don't get to explore any new avenues unless of course you they are very cheap or free.

title: Reasonable
pros: The people you work alongside are very friendly and great to work with
cons:
Lack of organization, consistently mixing up or losing paperwork related to shift changes/time off requests, the system is extremely inefficient. 
 Frequent last-minute scheduling changes e.g. getting voicemails at 11 pm to add a shift for the next day 
Consistently scheduled not enough staff to meet demand, particularly on weekends

title: Small and complex organisation
pros:
1. Flexible work arrangements, 
2. Most people are good to work with, 
3. Location in the city next to Parliament station, 
4. Office is nice on level 34
5. Generally the culture is good.
6. Good experience career progression for junior staff.
cons:
1. Culture of bullying (swept under the carpet by management), 
2. Highly political (different teams don't work well with each other)
3. Hierarchical (necessary levels)
4. Don't live their own values
5. Not trusted by their customers (health services)
6. Too many processes (feedback on change not usually acknowledge)

title: All stick... no carrot... How dare you ask.
pros: There are nothing but expensive high end restaurants around to eat at, so you'll never have to worry about saving money on lunch again.
cons:
Everything about this place, and yeah, I mean everything. 

No benefits other than increasingly expensive and worse Healthcare. 
No 401k matching
No bonuses
Maybe, just maybe... Merit increase that's 1 % above inflation. If you're lucky.

Long hours are expected and never rewarded. Anything to meet the deadline should be met with reward, instead it's 'what have you done for me lately' and get it done. How about no? 

They're always on a stupid deadline made because of rushed promises
Always behind schedule. Always cutting corners and taking the easy way out design wise. Leaving technical debt to build for years that insurmountable. 

Turnover is ridiculous and employee burnout is a serious issue. Moral is non existent because of the management style and dwindling benefits. 

Management is only in it to retire and sail off into the sunset on the backs of their workers dedication. 

Mismanagement has killed this place and nothing is left but ineffective cronies. 

Management will tell you whatever they can to get more work out of you. Promise bonuses and never deliver, say they'll do nice things for the team and then move the goal posts. 

Management fires essential staff, overloads employees with extra duties for the same pay, and expects no change in output. 

Management is bad and never should have been allowed to run this company into the ground like they have.

title: Work life balance in North Phoenix
pros:
This company is small enough you can get to know everyone and people are open and friendly.  A chance to really work on some challenging new/useful technology in AZURE and DevOps.  The movement to use new and growing technology is nice.

Centrally located in North Phoenix

Management is pretty liberal about WFH Tuesdays.  My dog loves it when I walk him 3 times a day on Tuesdays!

Annual bonuses here aren't life changing but they are not trivial.
cons: Communication between teams is hit an miss.  Its a problem when it is inaccurately assumed that "everyone knows" about a particular project.

title: Mid-sized company with a great working environment

Lean operation with the ability to make quick decisions
Generous PTO for new hires and flexible work from home policy
cons: None so far that I have found.

title: Unrealistic expectations with moving goal posts
pros: Truly fascinating technology, always something new to learn, build and integrate
cons:
As others have stated huge issues with development debt. As the company grows employees are expected to increase output in both development and front line support with essentially a skeleton crew. Average dev team has 2 developers and 1 QA. No additional employees have or will be hired to handle the workload. 

Employee burnout is systemic. In the past three months alone there have been key staff turnover over numerous departments. 

VP layer lives in their own world. Their technology is a house of cards

title: Long Term Substitute teacher
pros: Long term rate cant be beat at $226/day. Everyone I work with is amazing. Great teachers, principals, etc. But really difficult kids (If you can hang, without losing your cool, you'll get some damn good experience).
cons:
51 weeks a year, 3 sick days. If you cant find a job, or miss a day for any reason (including jury duty), your rate will drop from $226/day to $110 for 30 days. It amounts to about a $3000 loss. Its painful. We can accrue up to 48 hours, but under no circumstances are we allowed to use it.
Also, they just laid off of a bunch of teachers, so future job prospects are uncertain.

title: Unethical

cons:

Maybe once a year at the company get together.
But H.R. has no idea what the day to day in a moderate/severe classroom is.
They look for little slights to make you fear for your position.
It trickles down from the top. Clueless management to employees who are lost.. To the clients/parents/public....

title: Come work here!
pros: Canfor is the most real company I have ever worked for.  Real individuals, with real concern for managing and leading the business for continued success. A professional yet fun company that cares a lot about community enrichment. Canfor offers good salaries and employee perks, there is a continual focus on safety, and it is led by competent staff. Overall there is great morale in the company.
cons: Vacation time is lacking, especially in the first 5 years, compared to other large competitive firms (especially public service), but this is offset by other valuable (both tangible and intangible) perks.

title: the pros outweigh the cons
pros: defined benefits, paid schooling, 3 weeks vacation after first year, room to grow within the company. good working environment between workers. fair wages and
cons:
no mentorship for apprentices.  the water is filled with sharks, be careful if you openly give an opinion that differs from management. They have the power, they make the rules.  if they don't like what you say you could be out the door. 
course quote that i liked. 
"you are allowed to disagree, you are not allowed to disobey "

title: Great company with great values!
pros:
Their #1 value at Canfor is Safety comes first.  And that should be assumed in an industry-based company, but not always.

They have provided me many opportunities to grow my own skill-set and even paid for some additional schooling
cons:
Off the top of my head, I would maybe say there should be a payroll increment system that automatically adjusts your salary based on years of service.

And I gave it only 4 out of 5 stars, only because I believe no person or company can ever be perfect

title: Can Fam 👍
pros:
People at Canfor often say that it's like a family and it's true. It has a culture like nowhere else I have worked. 

 Lots of opportunity and ability to get involved in exciting company-changing projects, career progression and development programs. If you are  willing to jump in and get stuff done, you will be successful (and maybe even have fun) at Canfor.
cons: Like any company that is changing with the times (or ahead of the times) there is a lot of work to be done. I know the company is working on creating more diversity in the workforce and there is work still to be done at Canfor and across the industry.

title: Growth
pros: At Canfor, it is encouraged to expand your knowledge base, continue to challenge yourself and aspire to greater things.  They will utilize you where your strengths will be put to great use.  There is always opportunities to move within the company, and there is a continuous feeling of appreciation from coworkers/managers.
cons: Things are always changing, so you may just be getting very good at your job, and you may be put to use in another area, which requires a shift in thinking and time management and skills utilized.

title: Canfor is a top employer

- Great work/life balance
cons: - Benefits including vacation day allotments could be more robust to attract more people

title: Offers excellent career growth opportunities and compensation.
pros: When I was looking forward to start my career, as a fresher, mother of an one year old, XLD gave me the first opportunity to excel. After completing five successful years, I had to take a break for couple of years to take care of my family. When I decided to restart my career, the first door I knocked was XLD's and got my second opportunity. XLD not only pays the highest compensation in the industry but also provide excellent career growth to the employees. Perfectly drafted SOPs, Checklists and Focus on Training are of great assistance to the employees. Transparency and 'No Politics' work environment are the add-ons. I developed the practice of never repeating a mistake and learning from other's experience only because of the work culture in XLD, which helps me in my personal life too. Looking forward to grow further professionally.
cons: There is no practical difficulties.

Stable work
cons:
Very slowly growth
Lack of good managers

title: A growing City
pros: Fun environment, great people to work with
cons: The drive was horrible to get to work!

title: Great for entry level, not so great for growth
pros: Small team, lots of opportunity to get hands on with many forms of high level technology
cons: No growth, flat organizational structure, low(er) pay on the scale

title: Corrupt local government
pros: Decent pay, decent insurance, decent schedule
cons: You will go no where  unless you're part of the good ol boys club

title: Good for learning
pros: You will learn under pressure.   It’s sink or swim.  You will gain experience you can take elsewhere.
cons: Tough culture.  I felt morally compromised working here.  They don’t care about residents or employees.  The culture is toxic.   The owner is disconnected from employees.   It’s clicky.  They give housing discounts and raises without method.  If they don’t like you, you may get 10%.  If they like you, you may get higher (but you won’t know in advance).   The commission is really bad.  Moral at the property level is bad.   The owner has been known to visit properties and fire the whole staff not caring why the teams aren’t performing.

title: If you like being micromanged this job is for you!
pros: Pay was ok, lots of locations, great residents for the most part.
cons: Long hours, micromanagement, no training, multiple weekly meetings with no point or need, promised the world at your interview.  You hire a manager, let the manager run their property.  More time spent doing remedial unneeded tasks set forth by corporate to justify their high paying jobs.  Weekly meeting with disrespectful upper management to go over the same things over and over.  High rent increases (5-15%) lead to people moving, then you get blamed for not having vacancies.  Report after useless report after useless report, just let the EXPERIENCED property manager run their property.  If they need help, they will let you know.  Lots of apartment and employee turnover here.  Due to high turnover there is decent chance to move up but only if you are good at kissing behinds.  "Yes" men so to speak, do well here.

title: Good Place
pros: Nothing too terrible to say, most days were great.  Perks of being in the office included use of the gym, Starbucks Coffee and the random days there were treats for the employees.
cons: Again, nothing too terrible to say.  Only con I would say would be the strict policy of having a minimum 10.5hr day and starting at 7:30PM.

title: Worst Company To Work For!
pros: There are no pros with this company
cons: I had worked for this company for almost 4 years. In the beginning it turned out great with the team I was in. But as the company started expanding with more properties and employees it went downhill from there. They started giving people who did whatever they wanted the higher positions while all the people under them did all of the hard work with lack of pay. There was lack of training and guidance. Thank God I am a hands on person and learned quickly on my own and had to teach myself because my questions always were unanswered. I can only say there were two people in the entire company that were amazing and helpful to me. This company only cares about themselves and the income coming in. They could care less about you or your families needs. Thank God I have moved on!

title: Working for JRK was a great experience!
pros: Working for JRK was a great experience! My first hotel and it set the bar for hotel standard. From Front Desk, Concierge, Club Lounge, Rooms, Reservations, events, sales. Great place to work for, to learn and grow within the company.
cons: Clients at the hotel can be very very rude!

title: I have learned so much about property management and residents.
pros: Great vision, mission, and structure. I have learned so much about property management and residents. Very busy, lots to do, lots of work, but it makes the day go by faster.
cons: Lots of work but not really a con for me

title: Great systems in place
pros: Willing to teach qualified candidates, positive environment.
cons: No training system.  You have to deal with a lot of unhappy tenants.

title: It’s fine for now
pros: Good pay for a leasing position
cons: Sleazy company with lack of morals

title: Don't Believe the Reviews
pros: Fairly good pay, and you'll bond with co-workers...you know...in the way that people who have gone through a disaster together and survived bond. There are a few bright shining lights who work there and are decent, but when being a decent coworker makes you stand out its a bad sign.
cons: When their rating gets too low they post bogus positive reviews on here, although, who ever is posting them is clearly overworked as well, since they recycle almost verbatim the same wording with details changed. If its a sycophantic review raving about the company...its bogus. Extreme hours, nights, weekends, all-nighters, people have stories of sleeping at their desks.

title: Great pay! Not for the weak!
pros: Advancement, pay, support and travel.
cons: Work/ life balance is heavily tilted towards work.

title: The craziest company I ever worked for!
pros: You can miss several days of work and they will still let you slide! You can come to work high and drunk and they will not care. You can yell at residents. Cool employees and fun holiday parties.
cons: If you are someone starting in the industry, this is a good place to start to get your foot in the door elsewhere. But do not stay! No job security. You will get fired for doing your job. They lie to you about commissions and bonuses. Sometimes they will clean house and fire everyone all in one day. They bring ‘floaters’ to ‘clean’ everything up. They will hire ANYONE! People with no driver licenses, no experience, and they do not train! Everyone talks about everyone’s business. If you are sick or injured, they will fire you. Imagine an owner that makes you hide all your maintence staff when he is on property.  They make you rent 10 apartments each week or you will get written up. If there are bad reviews on google, you will get written up. They make you work after hours and don’t pay you. They don’t follow any rules or guidelines. You will never take a full lunch. Don’t bother bringing anything up to HR, you will get fired for doing so. If you show up to work and try your best, they will fire you versus someone that comes drunk everyday and is sick every week. I’ve had 5 different managers in the two years I’ve been there. If you want to get fired, work for JRK! This is the worst company in history. I’m surprised they are still here. The 5 star reviews about anything JRK is completely fabricated. All lies! They treat floaters that have been there for years like crap! Once you start seeing floaters come. RUN! They are robots. There were maintenance techs selling drugs to long time Regional maintenance Supervisors. I saw sexual harassment on a daily basis. Discrimination and lots of inappropriate comments made by Regionals. They give you a heads up when someone gets fired so you can watch and pretend that you didn’t know. Anyone that works for JRK are staying because they have no choice or have housing. But trust me, there is better out there.

title: Run far away from this company
pros: Can’t think of any sadly
cons:
If you are looking to get into the industry, this company is the last option you want to choose. They offer no training or support, so if you’re new to the industry, good luck. They DO NOT pay their vendors back. We had apartments with multiple roof leaks that couldn’t get fixed because they didn’t pay our vendor and they refused to complete the work. They choose the laziest and cheapest company for pest control so there were multiple apartments (including our model apartment) that often had roaches. 

The insurance that the company provides for employees is a joke. You can tell that JRK doesn’t put ANY money towards it because there is no reason why it should be well over $100 for single person w/ no kids for BASIC health insurance. 

I never saw a dime of commission during my time here. The managers were so slack and lazy and simply didn’t want to be bothered with the paperwork. And don’t buy anything for this company on your dime because you will not see it reimbursed for MONTHS.

Residents pretty much hated living at the property and always complained that there are always new people in the office.

There are so many more instances that i can bring up that show how horrible this company is. Not making apartments ready for move in, not paying vendors, etc. It’s sad that the way this company does business. You have beautiful properties with a lot of potential and amazing employees, yet it is clear that they are more focused on profits that actually keeping residents and their employees happy. If you are looking for a new company or a new place to live, RUN AND DON’T LOOK BACK.

title: Beware
pros: They entice you with a great salary
cons: Most Asset managers and above have never been in Property management. So your teams are taking direction from people who do not have a clue and will not listen to onsite staff.

title: Worst Company they are so cheap
pros: There are no pros to working here
cons:
They don't want to give over-time but expect you to work over time
They don't take care of their properties and expect you to lease unsanitary apartments.
They have an issue responding to issues

title: Horrible place to work
pros: You can gain experience
cons: Terrible upper management, too micromanaged and bullied! They never train you, absolutely no organization, they do not care for their residents which makes it difficult  to like the overall environment at work!

title: MICROMANAGE FROM CORPORATE OFFICE
pros: Pay is good because the work /life balance is awful.
cons:
Corporate is vulgar and disrespectful
No Support
No on-boarding or cross training
High staff turnover due to corporate micro-managing
Does not care about residents or staff

title: No Organization
pros:
Good pay
Not much else
cons: Upper management don’t care about their employees

title: Miserable Experience
pros: Nothing. Absolutely nothing about this company was a positive experience.
cons: I was told during my job interview that I would be challenged, the only thing that was challenged was my patience until I finally quit. This company DOES NOT allow you to have a satisfactory work-life balance. As an entry level employee starting work before the winter holidays, I had no PTO accumulated and was forced to work the full week of Christmas. I asked my manager and HR for unpaid time off and was denied my request and harassed when they called me in for a meeting to tell me that I had to work this week because I agreed to only take 2-weeks of vacation time annually when I came aboard as a CDM Smith employee. I was forced to work that week even though there was no billable work for me to do. I sat in the office reviewing past projects with nobody to help me or respond to my questions. My manager had no out of the office life and expected me to live the same way. When asking to go to job sites, I was told that only my managers could go to the sites and I would have to earn that responsibility. It was a mistake for me to work here, I hope nobody else has this much of a miserable experience, DO NOT WORK HERE!!

title: Best employee experience and collaborative work environment
pros: Co-workers are smart, friendly and easy to work with.  The fact that this is an employee-owned business (and intends to stay that way) allows for greater collaboration to find solutions.  I've worked in publicly-traded companies most of my career and there is truly a positive difference in working at an organization that doesn't have to meet stock market expectations. The leadership team is  intelligent, engaging and exhibits a strong desire to make the employees here successful.  In my experience, if an employee reports a problem in good faith using one of many avenues available to her or him, the matter is resolved.   The management team is very transparent and not afraid to challenge the organization to do better.
cons: I haven't found anything significant. I've worked at a number of companies over the last 25 years and you learn that the "grass is not greener" on the other side. So there's always going to be something people will complaint about; but this has turned out to be one of the best companies I've ever worked for.

title: Mixed Bag
pros: Most employees are genuinely passionate about their work. It is an environment that I generally enjoy coming to every day. The company has a wide variety of projects and enough internal latitude to usually work with the teams and projects that are of interest. Work-life balance and flexibility is above average for the industry, but on par with modern work place attitudes. Excellent opportunities to develop from a technical stand point.
cons: Leadership is pretty out of touch and still maintains an air of "you should feel lucky to have a job here". Compensation is subpar, particularly in competitive regions during an economic boom. Managers would rather hire external candidates than promote from within. Generally there is a disconnect between the brand image of success and the touted employee-centric culture. Performance evaluation is often done by people you have never worked with.

title: Good place to work overall, but there is room for improvement.
pros: Flexible hours, ability to get paid overtime, sit/stand desks, good work culture.
cons: Low pay for the cost of living in the area, company does not provide support for professional development (you must pay for programs yourself AND you must take PTO to attend programs) which is especially difficult for new engineers trying to learn and grow, not enough design work for younger structural engineers, terrible time sheet system that takes half an hour to fill out every week, NO paid maternity leave (only unpaid, 12 weeks and you must have been working for the company for at least a year to get the "benefit" of UNPAID maternity leave).  Health benefits are very good, but very expensive.   Raises are 2-3% each year, which is a pitiful outlook for people wanting to stay with the company for a long time.  Overall, a lot of these cons work together towards one underlying principal that the bottom line is the most important thing to CDM Smith.

title: Prime Example of the Negative Aspects of Corporate America
pros: Good compensation, interesting projects, professional environment and available training for employees.
cons:
Management is located in corporate office which are not really in touch personally with their employees and rely feedback from their management collegues. Therefore, they are out of touch with actual conditions in the office and existing environment.
Support Divisions such as Finance and Accounting dictate corporate procedures catered to field  which make it extremely dificult to understand and diffucult to manage projects efficiently and effectively. 
Company does not care about their employees. They basically treat employess as just numbers to them.
Too much waste and inefficient  making the company not competitive with others.
Too much company politics and favoratism. Some employees are in positions that should not be in and have too much authority.
Not a fair company to work for.

title: Competitive Salary and Flexible Working Environment
pros:
- Competitive salary
- Excellent healthcare benefits benefits  
- Flexible work environment: Ability to work from the office and/or from home
- Overtime pay
- Diversity of transportation projects, across all modes
- Opportunity to work on projects outside of your region
- Company support for involvement in committees, societies, and certifications
cons:
- Physical office location in suburbs
- Travel to remote/rural areas of the state
- Lack of opportunities to attend industry conferences

title: As far as large consulting firms go...
pros:
Flexible work hours, interesting projects, everyone who works there is intelligent and good at what they do
Good health benefits
cons:
Upper management and local management are not on the same page
Raises are pathetic and do not reflect the local cost of living increases
UT pressures are emphasized on engineers and scientists while admins in corporate charge overhead for sitting around, but that's just the horrible horrible world of consulting

title: Great Company, but some managers need to clear out of the way
pros: Diverse engineering firm that has some extremely intelligent and skilled people working there.  The ability to work across different offices when extra help was needed was really easy, and the ability to connect and network with people who are doing things that you are interested in is a great benefit.   Senior leadership is fantastic and supportive of the employees.    If you have the initiative, there is great support for training and opportunities to engage in your community.
cons:
Some managers are out of touch.  
Constant push to use Bangalore India staff when most of the local teams will rarely see the value (i.e. are they really working themselves out of a job so that leadership can see a higher bonus next year?  Try as you might to advertise the benefit, junior employees will ALWAYS be skeptical... as they should be.)
Project Managers are becoming strictly data sources and data inputters.  That's it.  Most of us PMs still like to have some engagement in the technical details (or, at least they should be).   Don't let the PM's become so disconnected that they lose touch with the details of the project or with the project teams.

title: Positive work experience
pros: I have been working for CDM Smith for 3 years now and I really like it here. I have had a steady stream of work that both challenges me and interests me. Occasionally I get frustrated due to "moving targets" with projects, but that is usually out of the hands of our PMs. I feel like any job is what you make of it and CDM Smith in no exception. Reading some of the other reviews about micromanagement and no work-life balance... nobody can force you to work over-time, so if you don't want to, then don't. CDM Smith does not hold you back if you want to work over-time though, if you want more hours/pay they won't bat an eye. As for the PTO, you don't get any right when you get hired but accumulation seems pretty good, and your benefits start immediately, which saved my life. Three months into me working here I became extremely ill and racked up a hefty ER bill. Because my benefits were already activated, I only had to pay $150 out of pocket, which is amazing. I also am currently undergoing immunotherapy, which can be extremely expensive if not covered well or at all, and I haven't had to pay anything but 2 copays. They allow us all to work remotely if we want/need to, all we have to do is give our managers a little heads up. I've never had issues with just a day or even day-of notice of needing to go work from home. As someone previously mentioned they have access to a plethora of training, including training on ESRI software, which is what I use everyday, and at no cost. Overall, I've had a positive experience here so far.
cons: Sometimes the annual raises can be a bit slim. I worked immensely hard my first year and was juggling three very large and long-term projects when I was originally hired to only handle one type of project for two years, and I only saw a 2% raise that year due to HR rules. That was a bit disheartening at first because I felt all my hardwork was not paying off, but the following year's raise made up for the discrepancy, mainly because my manager put his foot down with HR to give me something better than 2%.

title: Everyone Here Stays For Years!!
pros: The work environment is great, offices are nice (and usually downtown located), there are multiple offices in the US so you can transfer if you have to, projects are interesting!! I'm new but everyone in my office has stayed in the firm for over 10 years. It's my first full-time job out of school but I love it!!
cons: Like all consulting firms, you need to look for billable work, so if you don't have a major project, you might have to be asking around for work.

title: It's a Job
pros:
Good starter job.
The company sounds impressive. You'll might have lots of tiny opportunities to work on a breadth of govt. contracted projects.
Good for smokers.
cons:
Some people get stuck with the same project for years.
Salaries are not competitive; many of my coworkers are underpaid. 
You have to constantly badger other coworkers to find spare work. 
Sick, Personal, and Vacation days are all treated as the same PTO.

title: Great firm overall with just a few hiccups

cons: Higher ups  (not in the office) aren't pushing to be more competitive with pay; Can be slow to promote deserving individuals

cons: As an engineering firm, there's not too much emphasis on developing new cutting edge services. It's more maintain and support the current systems and occasionally do something new.

title: Great, laid back culture
pros: Flexibility and freedom to pursue your career - there are few barriers to advancement early in your career, later it becomes more challenging but that is true for any company; great benefits

title: Hard to climb the ladder
pros: Awesome learning experiences and a relaxed and great culture/atmosphere. Everyone feels more like a family than  just coworkers with a ton of resources. A great PTO benefit compared to other similar jobs.
cons: If you get hired in entry it's hard to climb. If with a promotion the pay is hard to match your gained experience.
